summary: Paul Merson reignited a feud with Andros Townsend after criticizing the Tottenham midfielder's brief seven-minute appearance in a 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously sparked controversy by stating Townsend’s England selection showed the team’s standards were too low. However, Merson admitted he was wrong after Townsend scored a stunning equalizer for England against Italy, acknowledging the goal as deserving praise. Despite Merson’s apology, Townsend responded on Twitter, defending his place in the England squad. Although tensions appeared to ease, Merson couldn’t resist revisiting the issue after Tottenham’s match, reigniting the feud.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. If the transfer is completed, Muto, who would become Chelsea's first Japanese player, will join their Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and earned 11 caps for Japan, scoring once. Despite a reported £4million bid, Muto remains undecided about the move, calling it an "honour." Ogane emphasized that Chelsea's interest is unrelated to their recent £200million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, which will become Chelsea's shirt sponsor starting in the 2015-16 season. Muto has started the current season strongly, scoring three goals in four games. Chelsea is also considering a pre-season tour in Japan.

A large-scale study published in Pediatrics found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The Finnish study, involving over 12,000 children, revealed that those who received antibiotics as infants were particularly prone to weight gain, with boys being more affected than girls. Repeated antibiotic use before age two also increased the likelihood of obesity. While the study did not prove causation, researchers hypothesize that antibiotics may disrupt gut bacteria, potentially freeing up more food for the body and increasing appetite. Lead author Dr. Antti Saari emphasized the role of antibiotics in the global childhood obesity epidemic and stressed the need for judicious use. The study also highlights broader concerns about antibiotic overuse, including resistance and loss of effectiveness, amid warnings of potential superbug outbreaks.

A Buckingham Palace guard embarrassingly slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, witnessed by hundreds of tourists. The incident, captured on camera by holidaymaker David Meadwell, occurred as the guard lost his footing, hit his bearskin on the sentry box, and dropped his rifle. The guard, who quickly got up while blushing, is believed to have slipped due to the metal protectors on his boots. The ceremony, which attracts thousands of tourists, involves fully operational soldiers and not just ceremonial participants. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The classic miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and drew over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E networks for a 2016 release. The new version will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, focusing on the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery. LeVar Burton, who starred as Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake, which promises to be "original" and "contemporary," drawing more directly from Alex Haley's novel, "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." Producers will work with historians to ensure authenticity. Executive producer Mark Wolper, son of the original's producer, highlights the enduring importance of Kinte's story. The remake aims to reach a new generation of viewers in a time of significant racial and cultural awareness, including the presidency of Barack Obama and the success of "12 Years a Slave." Burton emphasizes the story's ongoing relevance for younger audiences unfamiliar with its historical significance.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has claimed that palace aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in 1978. Lawler, now 64, alleges that on his first day working there at age 27, he was groped and pinned to a chair by male staff members, leading him to leave the job the same day. His complaints were ignored for months, and he only contacted palace officials again last year following inquiries into alleged historical child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring. Lawler, who was threatened and intimidated after the incident, claims his initial complaint was met with anger from Clarence House. Although the Palace eventually passed his case to Scotland Yard, a retired aide denied involvement, stating he was elsewhere at the time. The Royal Household has pledged full cooperation with any police investigation, and the police have declined to comment while investigations continue.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, created a rap video set to the theme song of the '90s sitcom *The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air* to announce they are expecting a child. The video, featuring the couple rapping in a car, has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In the parody, Melissa shares their journey of moving to Happy Valley, Oregon, and the couple humorously recounts how they tried to conceive, only to succeed within two months. Melissa reveals her pregnancy with a positive test and shares a sonogram at the end of the video. The couple filmed the clip in five takes to share the news with loved ones living far away. They were surprised by its viral success and hinted at another video after learning the baby's gender. Jesse, a descendant of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, previously starred in a video where Melissa creatively revealed the pregnancy. This announcement follows a similar trend by a Pennsylvania couple last year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* was auctioned for $137,000 in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and skirt, originally slate blue-gray but faded over time, were part of over 150 items from the film sold by Heritage Auctions. The outfit, worn in key scenes, was part of James Tumblin’s collection, which he amassed starting in the 1960s. Tumblin, former head of Universal Studios’ hair and makeup department, purchased the dress for $20 when it was nearly discarded. Other notable auction items included a straw hat ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000), and a black bonnet ($30,000). The film, based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, marked its 75th anniversary last year and featured Hattie McDaniel, the first African-American to win an Academy Award, for her role as Mammy.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The incident occurred on a Saturday afternoon when the boy slipped from his mother's grasp and fell 10 to 12 feet into the pit. His parents quickly rescued him before emergency responders arrived. The child suffered minor injuries, including bumps, bruises, and a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs, who remained unapproached due to apparent fright. The boy was taken to the hospital and is in stable condition. Zoo officials reported that eyewitness accounts suggest the child was dangled over the railing, prompting the zoo to plan child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the incident, and witnesses expressed shock over the parents' actions.

A non-operational speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, was found pointing directly at a residential front door, raising concerns for the homeowners. The camera, part of a network of around 300 devices using outdated technology, was decommissioned in March 2013 when all fixed speed cameras in the West Midlands were turned off due to obsolescence. Speed enforcement in the region now relies on mobile units, motorway cameras, and traffic patrols. Birmingham City Council, made aware of the repositioned camera, plans to send an engineer to assess and potentially remove it. A pilot program involving updated digital technology is in development, but the Wellington Road camera will not be included. The homeowners could not be reached for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, stated he is fit and eager to participate, highlighting Jamaica's strong relay tradition and his commitment to making the country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed excitement about Bolt's involvement, anticipating a memorable event. The full Jamaican team will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed their support for Barcelona's basketball team by attending a Euro League match against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Despite the win, Real Madrid remains atop the Euro League division by points difference. Neymar, who recently led Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile, faced tough challenges during that match. Before the international break, Barcelona had moved four points clear at the top of La Liga after defeating Real Madrid. Neymar and his teammates are set to resume La Liga play against Celta Vigo, aiming for a treble of trophies. Neymar's sister Rafaella also attended the basketball game.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with 8,480 rescued from Friday to Monday, including 20 boats sending SOS calls on Monday alone. Save the Children fears 400 migrants may be missing after a reported capsizing off the Libyan coast, though the Italian Coast Guard has not confirmed the incident or found evidence despite search efforts. The rise in migrant crossings has led to increased rescues, with over 10,000 arrivals in early 2015, primarily from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. Since the start of the year, at least 480 migrants have died in the Mediterranean due to adverse conditions and overcrowded, abandoned vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal rather than Liverpool, despite not knowing the exact reason for Sanchez's decision. Sanchez, who had multiple elite club options after leaving Barcelona, opted to continue his career under Wenger and has made a significant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez might have been linked to negotiations over Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona but is delighted with the outcome. He praises Sanchez's adaptability, efficiency, and influence on the team. Ahead of Arsenal's clash with Liverpool, Wenger downplayed rumors of interest in Liverpool's Raheem Sterling, commending Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for his team's development despite challenges like the loss of Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's prestigious hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark). The 35-year-old, who recently concluded his Team Sky career, aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, surpassing the current record of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, with a strong track cycling background, described the Hour Record as a "holy grail" for cyclists and hopes to inspire others to challenge themselves. He plans to race in front of a capacity 6,000-strong crowd, with tickets available from April 19 and the event broadcast live on Sky Sports. This attempt marks his return to track cycling as he prepares for the 2016 Rio Olympics, where he aims to secure a British record eighth Olympic medal. Dennis' record may also face a challenge from Briton Alex Dowsett on May 2.

Serena Williams, twice French Open champion, described her tough victory over Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as an 'eye-opener' ahead of the claycourt season. Despite Williams' eventual 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3 win, maintaining an 8-0 career record against Errani, she admitted she was not as prepared for clay as she thought. The U.S. team, including Williams and Alison Riske, lost 3-2 after being defeated 6-0, 6-3 in doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, leading to their relegation to World Group II. Williams acknowledged the need to adjust her playstyle for clay, while U.S. captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the importance of working harder to return to the top tier next year. Williams' victory in the Australian Open marked her 19th grand slam title, fueling speculation about a potential sweep of all majors this year, though the French Open remains her least successful major.

River Plate is interested in re-signing Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. Currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco, Falcao has struggled, scoring only four Premier League goals this season. However, he recently excelled with Colombia, equaling their all-time scoring record. River Plate's vice president expressed the club’s openness to Falcao's return, stating "the doors are open," though acknowledges the deal is complicated. It is uncertain if Manchester United will retain Falcao or if he will return to Monaco.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from The X Factor in 2012, has become the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' dry shampoo campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson against vibrant city backgrounds, showcasing different hairstyles and outfits, including a wavy hair look with a black blouse and leather jacket, and a half-ponytail paired with a maxi dress. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and launched with a TV ad featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about working with Batiste, a product she regularly uses. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of her management group, highlighted the natural synergy between Henderson and the brand, anticipating a successful year ahead.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by police officer Pablo Torres on March 14 in Kenosha, Wisconsin, are outraged over a billboard featuring Torres erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association. Siler, 26, was killed after allegedly arming himself during a confrontation with Torres, who is on leave pending investigation. The billboard, thanking the community for its support, has been called "disrespectful" by Siler's family and friends, with family friend Kathy Willie stating it felt like glorifying his death. The police association claims no offense was intended. Siler, who was wanted on a felony warrant, was killed after a vehicle and foot pursuit. This incident occurred just 10 days after Torres shot Terry Knight, deemed justified by authorities. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border, with three militants also killed, according to Iranian state media. The attack occurred in Negur, southeastern Iran, and was claimed by the Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal, which opposes Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian officials have urged Pakistan to capture the surviving attackers. Jaish al Adal, active in Pakistan's Balochistan province, has previously targeted Iranian forces, including a 2013 attack that killed 14 border guards. Iran criticized Pakistan for not stopping such cross-border attacks, while Pakistan condemned the incident, pledged cooperation, and vowed to bring any militants to justice if found in its territory.

The passage discusses a political exchange in Japan's parliament regarding UFOs and extraterrestrial threats. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered a UFO from outer space, despite monitoring airspace and scrambling jets when necessary. The query came from Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler turned lawmaker, who has a history of colorful political and public activities, including promoting products, attempting "basketball diplomacy" in North Korea, and converting to Islam while practicing Buddhism. Inoki, known for his red scarf and chin, claimed to have seen a UFO but admitted uncertainty about alien existence. The discussion follows a 2007 debate by then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba on legal implications of defending against an alien invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts after breaking a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China. Concerned about cleanliness, he stood on the toilet's rim, which collapsed, causing him to fall and sustain injuries. Jin initially claimed he was squatting but later told police he was sitting when the toilet broke, possibly to avoid liability. Authorities deemed the incident accidental, and Jin received treatment for his injuries. Police reminded the public that toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl over four years and filming her and others with a hidden bathroom camera. The investigation began when the now-15-year-old victim found the camera in her home. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. Investigators discovered 41 videos, 34 showing victims showering, stored on his computer. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims, including juveniles, purchasing the camera specifically to record the victim. He is held on $500,000 bail, with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1. The case has been described as particularly horrific by local authorities.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a unique series of father-daughter portraits, featured in his latest book titled *Daughter and Salaryman*. In these images, teenage daughters stand calmly, smiling at the camera, while their fathers, dressed in sharp suits, leap into the air in energetic and often dramatic poses. The series highlights the fathers' playful side, described as expressing "strong excitement and hope," contrasting with their typically serious demeanor. The portraits are set against various Japanese landmarks, adding cultural context. While some older fathers appear to struggle with the physicality of the jumps, others embrace the concept with enthusiasm, even incorporating gestures like peace signs. The photos have garnered significant online interest for their quirky and imaginative approach to family portraits.

The passage discusses the potential return of Kevin Pietersen to the England cricket team following the dismissal of Paul Downton as managing director. Downton's exit has opened the door for Pietersen's comeback after his controversial axing in 2014. Pietersen, currently with Surrey, is focusing on the county championship season to make his case for reselection. During a recent team photo session at the KIA Oval, Pietersen was seen reflecting thoughtfully but also in good spirits, joking with teammates and photographers. Surrey is set to begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19, and Pietersen aims to regain his spot in the England team ahead of the Ashes series. His last international appearance was during the disastrous 2013-14 Ashes tour in Australia. Surrey will play Oxford MCCU in a match on Sunday as Pietersen continues his efforts to return to the Test set-up.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club threatened by relegation, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially fired after a poor run, he was briefly reinstated by owner Angelo Massone but was dismissed again following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, which left the team 16th in the league, six points from safety. Ze Maria, a former Brazil international with 25 caps, became the club's third coach this season after replacing Florin Marin in January. He will be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao likely regrets his loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in Monaco. Falcao, who joined United on a season-long loan after a serious knee injury, has struggled to perform, scoring only four goals. United must pay £46 million to make the transfer permanent, but this seems unlikely under Louis van Gaal. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played regularly and participated in the Champions League, although he acknowledges Falcao may have sought a more vibrant atmosphere.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a 'very tall' man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a 'distinctive' cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. The incident occurred on Saturday at a Union St dairy in east Christchurch, where the masked man demanded cash from the owner's 30-year-old daughter, causing her to flee the shop in fear. The robber stole the cash register till and approximately $1,500 in cash. No weapons were used, but the man remains at large. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online. The owner, Christina Chen, noted the unusual and frightening nature of this robbery due to the mask.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with underage students. Initially arrested on March 19 for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old boy, including kissing and allowing him to touch her breasts, Granado was released on bail and placed on administrative leave. A month later, she was arrested again after another 15-year-old boy accused her of having sex with him on consecutive nights in January. The incidents allegedly occurred in her car near a Dallas school. The second accusation came to light after rumors of another relationship surfaced within the school. Granado was released on $50,000 bail following her second arrest, and it is unclear how she plans to plead to the new charges. The school district stated that immediate action was taken to prevent her from interacting with students.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has gone viral, amassing over 500,000 views. The incident occurred when the dog, owned by a local bike shop owner, approached the water's edge near a crocodile sanctuary and was attacked. New Zealander Tim Weston, a tourist who witnessed the event, described the crocodile holding the dog for hours as crowds watched in shock. The video, shared on social media, sparked strong reactions, with some viewers calling it "horrible." Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta due to its mangrove-rich environment and nearby sanctuary, and encounters with humans are increasing because of urbanization. American Crocodiles in Mexico can grow up to 6 meters long.

Steve Bruce remains confident that Hull City can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, leaving them two points above the relegation zone with six games remaining. Bruce believes securing nine or eight wins in total might be enough to stay up, though Hull have only six wins so far. He acknowledged the team has struggled due to long-term injuries to key players like Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass, but insists the squad is up for the challenge. Southampton, meanwhile, moved up to fifth in the table with goals from James Ward-Prowse and Graziano Pelle, though manager Ronald Koeman faced internal issues after Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty against team rules. Bruce emphasized Hull's need to remain positive and hopes to secure crucial results against tough opponents like Liverpool, Arsenal, and Manchester United.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, was banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their SATs exam answers and altered some answers himself outside exam conditions. This led to the annulment of the entire school's SATs results for the year by the Department for Education. Despite Guffick's claim that he only intended to make answers more legible, a conduct panel found his actions constituted unacceptable professional conduct. Although his behavior was deemed dishonest, it was not classified as fraud or serious dishonesty. Guffick admitted to the allegations, expressed regret, and accepted responsibility for his actions, which were deemed deliberate and not done under duress. The decision to ban him was upheld, with an option to appeal within 28 days.

Anders Lindegaard, the Manchester United goalkeeper, has had limited playing time in his five seasons at the club, making only 19 league appearances and being relegated to third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite his struggles on the pitch, Lindegaard is content off the field, having married Swedish model Misse Beqiri, with whom he has a son, in a romantic Mauritius beach wedding in 2014. The couple, who have been dating since 2012, recently enjoyed a sunny day off together in Cheshire. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots and a significant Instagram following, frequently shares modeling photos. Lindegaard, who moved to the Premier League in 2010, has been advised he can leave United, with a potential move to FC Midtjylland falling through earlier in the year.

The glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite an estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid came from a Sotheby's employee for $260,000, aimed at initiating bidding. The letters, which are 10-feet-tall and were installed in 1976, are currently owned by former Yankee Reggie Jackson, who purchased them after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson, who attended the auction, expressed his desire for a new generation to own the iconic signage. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their off-field behavior after Sterling was pictured inhaling nitrous oxide and both were seen using shisha pipes. Despite the incidents, Rodgers chose not to discipline the players but emphasized their professional responsibilities as elite athletes, urging them to learn from the situation. With Steven Gerrard returning from suspension, Rodgers focused on preparing Liverpool for their FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, expressing hope that past near-misses in competitions would help the team progress. He did not confirm whether Gerrard would start but stressed his commitment to reaching the FA Cup final.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after Germany's 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifying win over Georgia, sharing a relaxed photo with his dog on Twitter. Having missed Arsenal's previous game due to illness, Ozil is expected to start against Liverpool. Despite rumors of a nightclub visit, manager Arsene Wenger dismissed them. Since recovering from injury, Ozil has excelled, contributing four assists and three goals since January. He expressed that he's adapting well to English football, appreciating the demanding schedule and frequent matches. Ozil, who joined Arsenal from Real Madrid in 2013, feels he now fits in "perfectly" with the Premier League's style.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has affirmed that the club is satisfied with manager Luis Enrique and has no intention of replacing him. Despite speculation about Enrique's future, Bartomeu praised his performance since taking charge last summer. Enrique, who signed a two-year contract, is focused on La Liga and preparing the team for upcoming matches, including their recent victory over Valencia. With goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, Barcelona continues to pursue three potential trophies this season. Bartomeu emphasized that discussions about Enrique’s contract will occur later, but the club is "very happy" with his leadership.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, providing a boost after their FA Cup semi-final loss. The deal, worth approximately £100,000 per week, will extend until 2020. Henderson, who has shown significant improvement under manager Brendan Rodgers, becomes the third key player to extend his contract, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson, signed from Sunderland in 2011, has excelled this season with 13 assists and 7 goals, positioning himself as a potential successor to Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard departs for LA Galaxy. Meanwhile, contract talks with Raheem Sterling are on hold until the season ends, though Liverpool's Chief Executive expressed optimism about Sterling's future at the club. Rodgers aims to secure Henderson amid plans for up to 10 player departures.

Filipe Luis has expressed his desire to stay at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Although he has faced challenges securing the left-back position since joining Chelsea in July, Luis remains committed to the club. His focus now shifts to the Premier League title race, as Chelsea leads the standings. Manager Jose Mourinho is keeping the team focused on winning their remaining nine challenging matches. Luis recently played for Brazil in friendly victories against France and Chile.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal, following significant backlash. Hughes, a Wasps player, was initially suspended and shown a red card for a reckless knee collision with North's head during a match on March 27, which left North unconscious and led to concussion-related advice for him to rest for a month. Despite accepting there was no intent, Hughes received a sanction at the original hearing. However, the appeal was upheld, deeming the incident accidental, and Hughes is now free to play. The decision followed criticism from various figures in the rugby community, including Wasps' captain and other former players. Hughes missed a Champions Cup game during his suspension but is unlikely to play until April 26.

Stunning sunsets in the Pacific Northwest, photographed by Seattle's Tim Durkan, were caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia. The fires, initially started by farmers burning grass, spread uncontrollably due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. Although rescue crews extinguished the flames, residual smoke traveled across the Pacific Ocean, carried by atmospheric winds, affecting Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red sunsets result from smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing red and orange hues to dominate, particularly during sunrise and sunset due to the increased atmospheric distance light travels. As the smoke clears, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will lose their vivid reddish tint.

A Missouri mom, Becky Schoenig, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was later found and returned with some unauthorized modifications: red spray-painted rims, red detailing, and an orange-accented steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously embraced the changes, posting a lighthearted photo and comment on Facebook. Despite her positive attitude, the car had a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana, requiring professional cleaning. Schoenig, who owns a restaurant called The Hot Pot, is creating a smoothie named after Mick Sexton, the man who found her car and alerted the police. Her upbeat nature has been noted and appreciated by her friends.

Manchester City players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season, with the squad collectively at risk of missing out on £12 million. The incentivized contracts were designed to align with financial fair play rules. Following a defeat in the Manchester derby, City is in fourth place, just four points ahead of Liverpool, who have a game in hand. The top four Premier League finishers qualify for the Champions League, but the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledged the team's poor form since the start of 2015, which has jeopardized their season. With seven losses and early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League, City now faces a challenging fight to secure a top-four finish. This outcome may also impact their ability to attract top talent, such as Juventus' Paul Pogba, with rivals Manchester United expressing confidence in signing high-profile players. City's remaining fixtures include games against West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, QPR, Swansea, and Southampton.

Manchester United's Under 18s secured a 1-0 victory over Manchester City in a 'mini-derby' at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the decisive goal via a superb free-kick. The match, which was free to attend, drew nearly 1,000 spectators and featured 13 English players, 10 of whom were Mancunian. United's team utilized a three-at-the-back formation with wingbacks, mirroring the senior team's tactics. Despite missed chances from Marcus Rashford and a late free-kick attempt from City's Javairo Dilrosun, United held on for the win. The result leaves United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City suffered their second loss in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League play-off series. The match showcased promising young talents, highlighting the potential for future first-team opportunities.

Joe Hart, the England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England. Hart, who celebrated his 50th international cap during the match, expressed admiration for Buffon's career and described him as an inspiration, particularly noting his continued excellence at 37 years old. Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, emphasized his desire to keep improving and adding to his caps, while also celebrating his milestone achievement at the Juventus Stadium. He expressed pride in representing his country and aims to continue performing well for both club and country.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to deliver online and mobile orders in 67 cities. This marks a shift as Chipotle had previously declined collaborations with third-party delivery services. A nine percent service charge will be added to orders, with Postmates' delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. Postmates uses independent contractors, similar to Uber. Chipotle's growth has attracted attention, including visits from presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio. Other fast-food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or implementing delivery services to capitalize on this growing market.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have appealed to the Justice Department to remove the death penalty as an option for convicted bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In a Boston Globe op-ed, Bill and Denise Richard explained the immense suffering their family has endured since the 2013 attack, which killed their 8-year-old son and severely injured their daughter. While acknowledging the brutality of the crimes, they argued that pursuing the death penalty would lead to prolonged appeals, forcing their family to relive the tragedy for years. Instead, they support a life sentence without parole to bring closure and focus on healing. The sentencing phase begins soon, following Tsarnaev's conviction on all 30 charges. The Richards emphasized their stance is personal and not reflective of broader opinions.

A custom-built Boeing 747, costing £400 million, has been transformed into a luxury private home for an unidentified billionaire. Customized over three years, the aircraft features bedrooms, multiple lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a conference room, and an 'aeroloft' with eight beds. The interior resembles a luxury hotel rather than a traditional plane, with plush decor, porthole-style windows, and a focus on comfort and exclusivity. The plane, which normally accommodates up to 600 passengers, is designed for a single tycoon and can host dozens of guests, offering an unparalleled level of luxury far exceeding commercial first-class travel. The design and layout were created by Greenpoint Technologies.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station (ISS). While the launch was successful, SpaceX's attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge failed, as the rocket landed too hard and tipped over. This follows a previous unsuccessful landing attempt in January. SpaceX aims to reuse rockets to reduce space travel costs significantly. The Dragon, carrying over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker, will dock with the ISS and remain there for about five weeks. Afterward, it will return to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of cargo, splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. This marks SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS, and the launch was delayed from Monday due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel, located inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas. This event is part of a contest hosted by NBC's *Today* show to award an Elvis-obsessed couple with the "ultimate wedding." The winning couple, announced on Monday, will marry on April 23 and receive a wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience show. Priscilla emphasized the chapel's first-class nature, clarifying that impersonators are not allowed. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, Tennessee, featuring Elvis artifacts. Couples must submit a video or photos with an explanation to compete for the prize. The Westgate Hotel, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, is where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can close the gap on Manchester City in the Premier League despite a demanding season. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet made their 47th appearances of the season in a 2-0 win over Newcastle, tying a record for most appearances in Europe's top five leagues. Liverpool, four points behind City, regained momentum after poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring early, and Joe Allen secured the win with his first Anfield goal. Allen acknowledged Newcastle's penalty appeal but focused on the importance of the victory. Liverpool aims to maintain pressure on City as the season progresses.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute following a swift counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis secured the win with several key saves in the second half. The victory moved Roma four points ahead of Lazio, while Napoli's winless run extended to five matches, leaving them fifth. Security was heightened due to past fan violence, with Campania residents barred from buying tickets and 1,000 police officers deployed, though no incidents occurred. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, but Pjanic’s impact was decisive. Napoli had a potential penalty claim denied, and De Sanctis excelled in goal to protect Roma's lead.

Doncaster Rovers' season has been uninspired, leaving them stuck in mid-table mediocrity in League One. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town, who had little to play for after their play-off hopes faded, resulted in a dull 0-0 draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. The lackluster encounter tested fans' patience, and Doncaster's media team struggled to compile highlights, ultimately posting a 27-second video featuring only 14 seconds of action. The clip briefly showed the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle, humorously labeled a "must-see" for football fans.

The passage describes Roland Giroux's unique relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish bred in Taiwan in 1986. Unlike cats and dogs, marine pets typically lack physical interaction with humans, but Giroux bridges this gap by massaging and playing with his fish daily. In a video, he gently cups and strokes the fish, which initially swims away but soon returns to his hand, appearing to enjoy the interaction. The fish becomes so sociable that it swims up his arm, circles his fingers, and even seems saddened when Giroux removes his hand. Previously bullied by tank mates, the cichlid grew more interactive after Giroux began feeding it frozen blood worms by hand. Over time, the fish began craving daily play, showing frustration if neglected. Giroux dedicates at least 15 minutes daily to massage and interact with his prized pet, showcasing their bond in videos uploaded to his YouTube channel.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' fiery character and his importance to the England cricket team. Stokes, known for his aggression, previously injured his wrist punching a locker at the Kensington Oval, a reminder of the need to channel his emotions constructively. Despite a slight back issue, Stokes has returned to the team after a challenging year. England coach Peter Moores has played a key role in managing Stokes' temperament, particularly after a clash with Marlon Samuels during a Test match. Stokes' natural exuberance and competitiveness are valued, as they bring energy and imagination to the game, but his aggression must remain controlled to ensure productivity in runs and wickets. England aims to balance nurturing his talent without suppressing his character, ensuring he reaches his full potential alongside other emerging players like Chris Jordan. The passage emphasizes Stokes' potential to grow and contribute significantly to the team in the future.

The Euro 2016 qualifier between Wales and Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium is a sold-out event with 33,000 tickets purchased. Both teams lead Group B with 11 points each, but Belgium tops the group due to a better goal difference. Wales, inspired by a 3-0 win over Israel, is in its best position to qualify for a major tournament since the 1958 World Cup. The victory has heightened expectations for Wales to secure one of the two automatic qualifying spots for the 2016 finals in France. Due to high demand, general admission tickets sold out quickly. Despite speculation about moving the match to the larger Millennium Stadium, the game remains at Cardiff City Stadium, preferred by the Wales squad for its intimate atmosphere. UEFA rules also prevent venue changes within 120 days of the match.

England's Under-17 squad, led by coach John Peacock, is preparing to defend its title at the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The Young Lions, who won last year by defeating Holland on penalties, qualified with a perfect record. They are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, starting their campaign against Italy on May 7. Notable players include Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, who are returning after missing the qualifiers. The team's other matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the top talents from Anderlecht's youth system. Despite interest from Arsenal and Barcelona, Patoulidis previously turned down a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to focus on his studies. Manchester City have engaged in discussions with Anderlecht's chairman to negotiate a compensation deal, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure promising young talent for the club's future.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, was found dead in a flat in Fulham, south-west London, at the end of March. She had been strangled and beaten, sustaining fatal injuries to her head and neck. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and told to return to a London police station for further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Santillan, who worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, had expressed her love for London and Paris on social media before her death. Detectives are treating the case with urgency, though it is unclear if her profession is central to the investigation. London Ambulance Service pronounced her dead at the scene on March 28 after being called to the flat.

Dawn, a woman who experienced seven miscarriages, was devastated to learn that a family friend, Jamie, stole £207 she had set aside for a gravestone for her son, Daniel James. Jamie, a convicted burglar living with Dawn and her partner (also named Jamie), and his girlfriend Carol were suspected of the theft. Despite initial denials, a lie detector test on *The Jeremy Kyle Show* confirmed Jamie's guilt. During the show, it was also revealed that Jamie had sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing to the theft but blamed Carol. Dawn expressed her heartbreak and betrayal, emphasizing the emotional significance of the gravestone. After the revelation, she broke down in tears and left the stage, later comforted by her partner.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women, children, and elderly individuals, in northern Iraq, with the coordination reportedly involving Arab tribal leaders. The Yazidis, a Kurdish-descendent minority group with an ancient religion, faced severe persecution after ISIS overtook their towns in summer 2014, including killings, displacement, and enslavement. The freed Yazidis were transported to Irbil by the Peshmerga. The release's motivation remains unclear. This follows previous releases of Yazidis by ISIS, who have been accused of extreme brutality, including massacres and sexual violence. The humanitarian crisis prompted international intervention, including aid drops and airstrikes against ISIS. The Yazidis, numbering around 500,000 in Iraq, have long been persecuted, often labeled as "devil worshipers."

Harry Kane, a standout player for Tottenham and England, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards after a remarkable season. Known for his animated celebrations on the pitch, Kane is now featured in an animated video by Copa90, showcasing his best goals and celebrations, including his 20th Premier League goal. The video, made using layered photographs to create an animated effect, highlights key moments like his long-range strike against Chelsea and his goal on his England debut. Released ahead of the awards ceremony, the video supports Kane's nomination against players like Chelsea's Eden Hazard and Arsenal's Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher has expressed support for Brendan Rodgers as Liverpool manager despite a season without trophies and likely missing Champions League qualification. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work, emphasized that Rodgers' future should not hinge on a single game and highlighted the challenge of integrating new players. He believes Rodgers can lead Liverpool to future success with the right signings. Carragher, through his 23 Foundation, has been aiding underprivileged areas in Merseyside, inspired by the support he received growing up in Bootle. Liverpool's recent FA Cup exit and struggles this season have increased pressure on Rodgers, but Carragher remains optimistic about the team's prospects with proper improvements.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to security concerns, despite it being a toy that fires sponge darts. Airport security officers deemed the brightly colored toy a security risk after it appeared on X-ray machines, conducting a thorough pat-down of the child and demanding the toy be handed over. James' father, Phil Hayward, criticized the situation as "ludicrous" and described the security staff as "over-zealous." The family, traveling to Lanzarote, complied to avoid missing their flight, and James was promised a replacement toy upon their return. Following the incident, East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their actions, citing government regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited objects, such as replica or model guns, from passing through security. After the holiday, James received a replacement Nerf gun purchased online.

A 31-year-old man named "Rich" from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, has posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He lists specific "requirements" for his ideal partner, including being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, skilled in household tasks, a good cook, and "great in bed." She must also enjoy the outdoors while being "a princess when need to be." Rich describes himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, non-smoking, non-drinking, successful, and "well-endowed," owning properties and enjoying luxuries like cars and bikes. He promises benefits such as accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, and gym membership. Rich emphasizes he is generous, open to "reasonable offers," but excludes former partners from applying. Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact him for comment.

FA chairman Greg Dyke is advocating for radical changes to increase the number of home-grown players in English football clubs, proposing to raise the minimum from eight to 12 per squad and altering the definition of "home-grown" to focus on training before age 18. He faces opposition from the Premier League but has the support of five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—who warn that failure to support these changes risks England falling behind other football nations. They argue the shrinking pool of English talent at top levels disadvantages the national team, despite recent promising players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane emerging. The managers stress the need for opportunities for these talents, emphasizing that England's lack of major honors since 1966 is partly due to limited access to top-level play. England's current Euro 2016 qualifying performance has been strong, but concerns remain about the long-term development of English players.

In the latest episode of "Poldark," Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, becomes a mother to a baby daughter, much to the delight of Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner. Despite marrying out of duty, Ross clearly shows deep affection for Demelza, indicating she makes him a better man. However, viewers have noted inconsistencies in the pregnancy timeline. The previous episode ended with the announcement of the pregnancy, while the current one jumps to Demelza being eight months pregnant and giving birth within minutes of screen time. This rapid progression mirrors a previous pregnancy involving Elizabeth, another love interest of Ross. Fans humorously remarked on the swift pregnancies in the show, noting the lack of acknowledgment of time passage. Despite Ross's appeal, his heart appears to be off the market.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has emphasized the importance of his team focusing on their own performance rather than worrying about their relegation rivals. Following back-to-back wins, including a 3-2 victory at West Brom with a last-minute goal by Jamie Vardy, Leicester remains bottom of the Premier League but is now just three points from safety. Pearson stressed that the team's future is in their own hands and urged them to stay focused on their remaining matches, warning against excessive optimism and distractions from other teams' results. He highlighted that Leicester must prioritize their own performance to have a realistic chance of survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island, across the Pacific Ocean, and down the U.S. West Coast to Baja, Mexico. Her journey surpassed the previous record of 10,190 miles by a humpback whale. During her migration, Varvara visited three breeding areas of eastern gray whales, suggesting she may actually belong to that population despite being considered a western gray whale. This challenges previous assumptions about genetic differentiation between the two groups. With only 150 western gray whales believed to exist, the findings could imply their numbers are even smaller. The study was conducted by scientists from Oregon State University.

A section of seabed measuring approximately 1,000-1,640ft long, 100ft wide, and rising 30-50ft above sea level emerged overnight along the coastline of Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu on Japan's Hokkaido Island. Geologists attribute this phenomenon to a nearby landslide, triggered by melting ice and snow, which caused a section of land to collapse and pivot the underwater area upwards. Local residents reported no sounds or tremors during the event, and marine organisms like seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the newly surfaced land. Authorities believe this incident is unrelated to earthquakes, including the recent 7.8-magnitude quake in Kathmandu, and do not expect further expansion of the landmass. The emergence came as a complete surprise to locals, who observed the change the following morning.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in the summer, reaffirming his love for the club despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a Champions League match. Van der Wiel insists he is happy at PSG, loves the club, the city, and his teammates, and has no plans to leave, even expressing a desire to sign a new contract. He accepts the coach’s decision not to play him but remains ready when called upon. However, PSG’s reported interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves raises questions about Van der Wiel's future, as he could potentially be sold.

Carlos Tevez is seeking to terminate his contract with Juventus to return to his former club, Boca Juniors, in Argentina. Despite having a contract with Juventus until 2016 and being the league's top scorer, Tevez has expressed his desire to leave this summer. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, emphasized that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus for the deal to be finalized. Tevez, who began his career at Boca Juniors, has long stated his intention to end his career there. Juventus, while reluctant to lose Tevez, has acknowledged his wishes and is looking for replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, supports the decision, affirming that playing for Boca Juniors would not negatively impact Tevez's Argentina career.

During a thrilling Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich secured a 6-1 victory over Porto, advancing to the semi-finals. Goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski overturned Porto's initial lead. Amid the excitement, Bayern's manager Pep Guardiola tore a hole in his trousers, humorously commenting on the incident. The match showcased Bayern's dominance, leaving their European rivals wary of their form. Guardiola also removed his suit blazer during the game.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, resulting in ten people being injured, including four children. Two patients, a 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy, were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest and shoulder injuries and chest pain, respectively. A 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also flown out for treatment. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. One person was trapped in their vehicle and freed by Queensland Fire and Rescue. The highway was closed south of Fernvale, with diversions in place, and police advised the closure would last several hours.

The passage discusses the upcoming Premier League clash between Arsenal and Chelsea, highlighting Arsenal's Mesut Ozil and his excitement over acquiring a new Apple Watch, which he compared to a gadget from the TV show "Knight Rider." Arsenal, trailing Chelsea by 10 points, is buoyed by the return of Jack Wilshere, who recently returned from injury. Wilshere's potential is widely acknowledged, but his career has been hampered by fitness issues. Arsenal legend Ray Parlour emphasizes Wilshere's importance to the team if he can stay injury-free, drawing parallels to Abou Diaby's struggles with injuries. Wilshere is expected to play a significant role as Arsenal aims to close the gap with Chelsea.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will oversee the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford, despite having sent off three players from both teams this season, including City captain Vincent Kompany and United's Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw. Kompany’s red card during a Euro 2016 qualifier means he is suspended for an upcoming match against Wales. Clattenburg, regarded as one of the Premier League's top referees, has faced past accusations of favoritism toward United but has issued only two red cards in the league this season, both to United players. The derby holds significance as United moved a point above City following their recent results, with second place potentially at stake. City have struggled since the start of the year, while United are on a five-game winning streak. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck, Jake Collin, and fourth official Jonathan Moss.

Outspoken federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as "a little black puppet on a string," suggesting racial undertones in their assumption that Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence and withholding his criminal history. Gordon, who quit the Labor Party but remains in parliament as an independent, has thrown the Queensland Government into chaos due to its razor-thin majority. Katter, of Lebanese descent, defended his use of the term "black puppet," citing his own experiences with racism and stating he deliberately used the phrase to criticize the Government's attitude. His comments drew criticism on social media, with some questioning his terminology, while Katter argued that Gordon would not become a puppet for the government like other independents in the past.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, who was born with cerebral palsy, is using dance to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and judgment due to her disability, Dayna creates enthusiastic videos to show that she can do many of the same things as others, just in her own way. Her goal is to change how people with disabilities are perceived in media and society, encouraging others to look past her condition and see her as an equal. Dayna also highlights her achievements, such as driving, attending college, and dancing, despite doctors initially doubting she would walk. Through her videos and motivational speaking at local schools, she aims to turn negativity into positivity, inspire others, and bring smiles to people’s faces.

Orlando City, an MLS team with a large Latin-American fanbase, have shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez would be a commercially attractive signing for Orlando, though eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, are also interested. United are willing to sell him for around £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A group of at least three individuals set a white Dodge Charger on fire at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles early Saturday morning. The incident occurred after the driver, who was pumping gas, got into an argument with the suspects, who reportedly attempted to carjack him. The suspects doused the car with gasoline and lit it ablaze while two passengers were still inside. No one was injured, but the car was severely damaged. The driver fled after the suspects pulled a gun on him. Surveillance video is being used in the arson investigation by the Los Angeles County Fire Department, and the suspects remain at large.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, surrendered his chiropractic license after admitting to unethical practices, including accepting sex as payment and performing exorcisms on patients. He also advised patients to stop taking prescribed medications. Manuel agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years and must demonstrate that the circumstances leading to his license revocation have been resolved before resuming practice. Despite the allegations, he received positive patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. His practice was based in the small town of Lamoni, Iowa, though it appears to have operated from a residential address.

A Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner," according to the Pentagon. The incident occurred in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. crew citing the Russian pilot's aggressive maneuvers and high speed as concerning. Russia claims the U.S. plane was flying toward its border with its transponder off, a claim the U.S. denies. The U.S. plans to file a formal complaint through diplomatic channels. This follows a similar incident a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk, where a Russian jet flew dangerously close to a U.S. aircraft. Such encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are common in regions like Northern Europe and near Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle, stored in a locked case secured with padlocks and chains, was taken after the thief broke the car window and used a rope and another vehicle to rip it free. The theft, which also included a gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools, occurred overnight on March 27 at the Marriott Springhill Suites. Police found skid marks, rope, and the broken case handle at the scene, while some items were later found at a nearby hotel. The rifle has not been recovered, and the hotel lacks surveillance cameras. The rifle's serial number has been flagged in a national crime database, and the Secret Service was notified but did not confirm increased security. It is unclear if the car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Canberra. The court heard that Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen stated that Costa likely suffered from dementia and alcohol abuse, which compromised his mental state during the incident. Evidence such as fluctuating mood during triple 0 calls and a trail of feces suggested confusion. Costa's state of mind is crucial to the case, as a not guilty verdict could be returned if his unstable mindset at the time is proven. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa might have feigned memory loss, but Professor Mullen denied this, stating that Costa likely had a demented illness leading up to the event.

In Everton's 1-0 win over Burnley, Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty instead of Leighton Baines, who has a strong penalty-scoring record, sparked debate. Barkley's effort was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper Tom Heaton, reminiscent of a previous incident involving Kevin Mirallas. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's choice, emphasizing that multiple players can take penalties based on their confidence at the moment. Despite the missed penalty, Everton won with a goal from Mirallas, ensuring Barkley's error did not affect the outcome. Martinez praised Barkley's responsibility and noted Baines' support for the decision.

Two passengers on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico were found dead in their stateroom, with the cruise line suggesting a murder-suicide. The incident was discovered by the cleaning staff, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified. The ship, which departed from Tampa on March 29, is currently in San Juan, and the cruise line is cooperating with the investigation.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, successfully began his tenure as coach of Curacao in World Cup qualifying. Curacao advanced to the second round in CONCACAF for the 2018 tournament after drawing 2-2 with Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. A crucial goal by Charlton Vicento in the 87th minute secured their progress. Curacao will next face Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, who has a personal connection to Curacao through his mother, previously reached the World Cup semi-finals as a player in 1998 and as an assistant coach in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, a highly decorated footballer with a career spanning victories in all major European competitions, expressed that helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League would be as significant as winning a trophy. Despite Leicester being seven points from safety with eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances. He emphasized the importance of staying in the Premier League, likening it to winning a cup. Cambiasso joined Leicester in the summer after a decade at Inter Milan, where he won 15 trophies, and has quickly become a key player. Although his current deal is for one year, he is happy in Leicester, both personally and professionally, and has not ruled out staying beyond this season. Previously, he also found success at Real Madrid and River Plate. Cambiasso acknowledged the difficulty of the task but believes Leicester can still survive relegation.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma, who has two children under five with different fathers, risks being banned from seeing her children due to her lifestyle choices. She handed over the care of her children to her 52-year-old mother, Debbie, when they were infants. Debbie, who has raised the children due to concerns from social services, is frustrated with Gemma's drinking, partying, and alleged theft to fund her lifestyle. Despite Gemma's protests, a lie detector test confirmed she stole from the family. Debbie claims Gemma has neglected her responsibilities as a mother since adolescence, prioritizing partying over her children, and now threatens to ban her from the house and their lives entirely. Debbie emphasizes her love for the children, who call her "mum," and her desire for Gemma to mature and take responsibility.

In a match between Chelsea and Manchester United at Stamford Bridge, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored a goal to make it 1-0. However, the Sky Sports pundits believed that the build-up to the goal included a foul by Chelsea's captain John Terry on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao. Terry's challenge from behind caused Falcao to fall, leading to a loose ball that Cesc Fabregas picked up, eventually assisting Hazard's goal. Pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed during their analysis that Terry's tackle, which involved an elbow to Falcao's back, was a foul and should have stopped play. Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao, stating he would have wanted the foul called, while Redknapp noted that despite Falcao possibly being able to stay on his feet, the challenge was still a foul.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway due to a blown rear tire, but all occupants, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The incident, captured on video by Michael Barnett, occurred on Interstate 30 near Dallas. Scott expressed gratitude for their safety and noted that the fire destroyed the bus's back lounge, except for her Bible. The band’s other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a Scottish scientist from Dundee University, is developing space lasers to convert sunlight into energy for powering homes. These satellites, equipped with mirrors, would orbit Earth, harvesting sunlight and converting it into laser energy, which could boost solar panel efficiency and provide power even in places like Scotland or disaster-hit areas. Unlike the destructive lasers in science fiction, these lasers would be far less powerful and incapable of causing harm. Dr. Quarterman’s project is currently in trials, with plans to expand testing to Portugal. While separate research in Tokyo proposes using lasers on the International Space Station to clear space debris, both systems are non-lethal and target small objects. However, Dr. Quarterman has noted concerns about the potential misuse of his technology if control falls into the wrong hands.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a history of obsession with young girls, has gone missing after leaving a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. Munden, who was detained under the Mental Health Act, was last seen on Tuesday at 6:15 pm. He was convicted last August for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus and possessing indecent images of children. Described as 5'8" tall, heavy-set, with dark hair, he may have shaved his beard before fleeing. Munden, who has learning difficulties and autism, was serving a hospital order at a private facility following his conviction. Authorities are urgently searching for him, as emphasized by Detective Chief Inspector Tim Rowlandson, who urged the public to report any sightings or information about his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts after being sued by Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, wife of former NBA team owner Donald Sterling. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men, and claimed Donald used their money to buy Stiviano luxury cars and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano denied wrongdoing, but the court sided with Shelly, calling it a victory for the Sterling family and a legal precedent for recovering misused marital funds. The dispute emerged after Donald Sterling's racist remarks on a leaked audio recording led to his downfall, including a lifetime NBA ban, a $2.5 million fine, and loss of ownership in the Los Angeles Clippers. The gifts in question ranged from luxury items to everyday purchases like a blender and clothing. Shelly Sterling's lawyer hailed the ruling as a significant legal win.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer activities, urging the club to sign four top players—goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker—to compete for the Premier League title. Speaking after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, Henry expressed doubts about Arsenal's ability to win the league with Olivier Giroud as the first-choice striker, despite Giroud's 14 goals this season. Henry highlighted Chelsea's signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as an example of what Arsenal needs to do to succeed. Arsenal, currently third in the league, are level on points with Manchester City but have a game in hand. Henry emphasized the necessity of strengthening the team’s core to foster competitiveness and title-winning potential.

A young woman who endured years of abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, a former Bega Cheese boss, has spoken in court about the profound impact it has had on her life. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including the persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who remained silent for years, broke her silence after learning Van Ryn had been caught. She expressed fears for her future relationships, stating he had stolen her right to share her body with someone for the first time. As a child, she didn’t understand the abuse was wrong or illegal, questioning if it happened to every child. Since speaking out, she has battled depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide, and fears judgment if others learn about her past. She also worries about how the abuse will affect her ability to trust men and is concerned about Van Ryn's eventual release. The hearing is ongoing. Support is available through Lifeline on 13 11 14.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is regaining fitness after being sidelined for over a year due to a serious knee injury. A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, tragically died after falling 70 feet down a cliff while attempting to avoid paying a taxi fare. Lacking sufficient money for the fare, the group planned to escape payment by pretending to use an ATM and then running away. Phillips fled into the dark, leaping over a fence and unknowingly running toward a cliff. His body was discovered the next morning by a dog walker at the base of the disused Northern Promenade. The coroner ruled the death accidental, noting Phillips likely became disoriented in the dark and was unaware of the cliff's proximity. The taxi driver expressed regret, stating he wouldn’t have left Phillips if he had known the danger. Although urgent cases received free fast-track upgrades, many had already paid extra fees and still missed trips. Only 2,191 compensation claims were approved, with payouts totaling £203,066, averaging £92.68 per claim. Ministers rejected calls for blanket refunds, citing concerns over setting a precedent. Unique details include vintage tins of products like Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk and quirky stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms. While some modern upgrades, such as double glazing, have been made, the house requires significant renovations, potentially deterring developers. Auctioneers suggest it would suit antique enthusiasts or families passionate about preserving historic charm. The auction is set for April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Buffy Summers is a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in a film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in a television series.
The passage states that the series "Make It or Break It" concluded with its third season, as announced on April 26, 2012. The series finale was broadcast on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a sub-field of computational linguistics that develops technologies to translate spoken language into text, utilizing knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Its applications range from voice user interfaces, like voice dialing and call routing, to speech-to-text processing in word processors and emails, as well as uses in aircraft and appliance control. Recent advancements in SR, evidenced by increased academic research and industry adoption, prominently feature deep learning methods. Major industry players such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, and others have adopted deep learning as the core technology in their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970. Originally named the Golden State Comic Book Convention, it was established by a group including Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. Alf served as the convention's chairman from its inception. The event later became known as the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
"Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally featured Bruce Lee as the lead character."

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking Sunderland's first Premier League win of the season. Despite taking the lead with a goal from Dan Gosling, their first in three games, Bournemouth was undone by goals from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. Bournemouth created numerous chances but failed to find an equalizer, even with Sunderland playing a man down after Steven Pienaar's dismissal. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration over the lack of goals despite creating enough chances to win multiple games, emphasizing the need to move on and learn from the defeat.

The passage discusses Australian policy on detaining migrants attempting to reach its shores by boat, which has been described as "brutal" and "inhumane" by the New York Times. The policy involves offshore processing camps and has been defended by Mr. Abbott, who argues it prevents deaths at sea. The passage also highlights criticism from Australian Jewish groups over Mr. Abbott's comparison of Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis, with Mr. Abbott later clarifying he is not in the "business of ranking evil." Despite backlash, Mr. Abbott maintains that stopping boats has halted deaths, referencing the tragic case of Alan Kurdi. European leaders have been warned against adopting similar policies.

Two incidents involved individuals being scammed by callers claiming to be from BT technical support. In the first, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked on September 15, and in the second, a woman from Stranraer lost money a week later after granting remote access to her computer. PC Siobhan Pellett warned about the alarming ease with which scammers access victims' computers and the significant sums stolen. Authorities urge the public to be cautious with unsolicited calls, avoid granting remote access to computers, and never share banking details over the phone, as reputable organizations do not request such information.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone, the third-placed Championship team, after departing Swinton Lions, where he was replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler. A former player for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford over a 16-year career, Duffy will make his Featherstone coaching debut in their final league game against Toulouse, ahead of the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy as a "fantastic coach," highlighting his impressive work under challenging circumstances at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew and a coastguard helicopter responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. The rider, who had head injuries and was severely cold from lying unconscious on wet sand, received treatment on-site before being airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to allocate part of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system, improving upon the current ground-based radar system.
