Earlier in the season, he was fined £25,000 for comments about a ‘campaign’ against Chelsea. Chelsea is currently leading the league.

TV legend Bob Barker returned to "The Price is Right" after eight years, hosting the first segment of the show on April 1. Barker, who hosted the game show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, led the classic "Lucky Seven" price-guessing game at the age of 91. He then handed over hosting duties to Drew Carey, who continued the show. Despite his long absence, Barker appeared energetic and seamlessly resumed his role.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday at 12:30 am for allegedly attempting to break into a house on the 3200 block of D Street SE. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Metropolitan Police Department reported that Baldwin was taken into custody by officers responding to the scene. Following his arrest, the Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin was assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which supports U.S. diplomatic activities under the State Department. He was scheduled for arraignment on Friday afternoon, and no attorney was listed in court records. Baldwin's arrest follows recent misconduct allegations against a high-ranking supervisor, currently under investigation by the Homeland Security Department's inspector general. These incidents add to ongoing scrutiny of the agency, including an investigation into a March 4 incident involving two officials allegedly breaching White House security while intoxicated.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture close-up images of a male lion at a city safari park. Armed only with a camera, Saeed left the safety of his car and approached within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to take a few shots. The camera's shutter sound alerted the lion, prompting Saeed to retreat rapidly back to his car. Reflecting on the incident, Saeed admitted it was a close encounter and questioned whether he would attempt such a feat again.

New York City police are seeking help to identify a woman found dead on a Brooklyn street in March. The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section and later pronounced dead. She had no identification but had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg, featuring a heart with a ribbon, rose, and the name "Monique." Police released images of the tattoo and a rendering of its original appearance. The cause of death is still pending a medical examiner's report. Authorities urge anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK, as they couldn't afford to buy property. Over a year and a half, they constructed a solar-powered, two-bedroom home using wood and steel, allowing them to live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand. The home features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and water sourced from a nearby spring, with electricity primarily supplied by solar panels. The project cost approximately $25,000, and the couple, along with their cat, now live surrounded by nature. They plan to build another similar home in the future.

A study by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those without iPads or those using individual devices. Shared iPad users scored approximately 30 points higher. The research, involving 352 students, suggests collaborative learning around the shared technology is key to improved outcomes. Blackwell recommends schools reconsider how tablets are used to maximize their effectiveness, particularly in early grades. These findings will be presented at the International Communication Association conference.

A two-legged piglet from Qionglai City in Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters due to being born without back legs. The heartwarming video shows the piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," wobbling and balancing with its snout to the ground while foraging for food. Despite nearly tipping over, it consistently regains balance and interacts with its siblings, who were all born with four legs. The piglet belongs to farmer Ms. Duan, who noticed the deformity at birth. Villagers have flocked to see the remarkable animal. This piglet is not the first two-legged animal to gain attention in China; a rabbit in Guangxi Province also drew crowds for walking on its front paws. The video has captured the hearts of thousands online.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a leg cut at the infield care center and was released. Many drivers faced traction issues due to earlier rain. Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd after spinning out on turn one.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally killed his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Severiano smashed her head into concrete 11 times and shot her in the face five times, later confessing that his jealousy of men looking at her drove him to commit the crime. The incident was captured on CCTV, showing Severiano dragging her body into their garden and carrying out the attack after a violent argument. Neighbors reported hearing him accuse her of being a "slut" and "whore." Severiano fled in a stolen car but was arrested after crashing it. Police found multiple weapons in his possession, and he now faces life in prison.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, known for her best-selling book *I Quit Sugar*, has spoken openly about her personal struggles with mental illness, revealing she nearly took her own life due to severe anxiety. During an interview with *Women's Weekly Australia*, Wilson, 41, described how mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation led her to a point where she "couldn't see the existential point of continuing." She expressed feeling alone, without a husband or children, and likened her younger self to someone who had "missed out on a guide book to life." Although she has found some peace in recent years, Wilson emphasized the link between anxiety and depression, calling anxiety the "new depression." She stressed the importance of addressing this connection to better support the growing number of Australian women affected by stress and anxiety. Beyond Blue reports that one in three women in Australia will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and while anxiety and depression are distinct, one can often lead to the other. Help is available through organizations like Beyond Blue (1300 224 636) and Lifeline (13 11 14).

Elena Curtin, a pregnant Oregon woman, will no longer face prosecution for assaulting her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. The incident occurred in November 2014 when Curtin found the woman using heroin in her bathroom. After the woman refused to leave, Curtin attacked her, leading to a charge of second-degree assault. Prosecutors dropped the charge, deeming Curtin's actions justified under Oregon's self-defense laws allowing physical force against intruders. Curtin's defense attorney claimed the ex-girlfriend had harassed Curtin and tried to sabotage her relationship. The boyfriend and ex-girlfriend have since reconciled, while Curtin, now a mother, lives with her parents and has ended her relationship with the boyfriend. If convicted, Curtin would have faced nearly six years in prison.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed reacting negatively to broccoli when her owner tricked her by mixing it with treats. Upon tasting the broccoli, Gemma displayed disgust and promptly spat it out. The passage humorously notes that Gemma, who also enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family, isn't setting a good example for the two children she lives with, hoping they don't follow her lead in rejecting vegetables.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed users to a pornographic page. The issue occurred when the page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which had been discontinued in 2011, was not renewed and was taken over by a porn site. Visitors attempting to access the awards page were shown explicit content. HSBC removed the link after discovering the error and assured the public that its website remained secure. A spokesperson confirmed there was no association with the porn site and apologized for the inconvenience. The bank emphasized that its internet banking services were unaffected.

A 13-year-old boy named Marcus from Clinton, Maryland, successfully guided firefighters during a 911 call after a fire broke out on the first floor of his family’s home, leading to his and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah’s rescue. Trapped in a second-floor bedroom, Marcus calmly provided instructions to the dispatcher, reassured his sister, and directed firefighters to their location. Firefighters entered through the home and broke a window to reach the siblings. Lt. Kenny Ward, a firefighter, handed Marcus out the window and gave his gas mask to Aaliyah, an act praised as heroic. Both siblings were hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries, while their mother, stepfather, and older brother escaped independently and were treated at another hospital. Marcus’s composure during the 11-minute call was credited with aiding the rescue.

Blue fluorescent algae, caused by the phytoplankton *Noctiluca scintillans*, lit up Jervis Bay on Australia's east coast, creating a stunning neon glow on one of the country's popular beaches. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the phenomenon, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene." The glow, produced by millions of plankton, occurs due to natural causes and serves as a defense mechanism. A similar event occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. According to Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales, this algae blooms in spring and autumn and is not a cause for concern.

New tests, such as Endopredict, can identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors to determine their aggressiveness and the risk of recurrence, potentially sparing some patients from undergoing chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are analyzed in a lab, and patients can learn within days if their risk of cancer returning is low—sometimes as low as 5%. For many women, this low risk makes chemotherapy unnecessary, as its benefits may not outweigh its severe side effects, including nausea, fatigue, and hair loss. While these tests are currently available mostly through private healthcare at a cost of about £2,500, experts like Professor Kefah Mokbel and surgeon Hemant Singhal argue for their adoption by the NHS, as they could save costs by avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy. Becca Cornford, a breast cancer patient and mother of three, opted against chemotherapy after her test results showed a low recurrence risk, highlighting how these tests enable more informed, personalized treatment decisions.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with at least one evacuated from the now-decommissioned HMS Illustrious and others from 18 additional ships, including HMS Dragon and HMS Enterprise. Data obtained via a Freedom of Information request revealed that HMS Ocean had five pregnant sailors evacuated over nine years. The Ministry of Defence enforces a strict "no touching" rule at sea, implying pregnancies likely occurred before boarding or during leave. The issue gained attention after Commander Sarah West, the first female Royal Navy warship captain, was flown home amid claims of a relationship with a crew member, prompting an investigation. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with females comprising 9% of personnel in 2014. Meanwhile, nearly 100 female soldiers were evacuated from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2013 due to pregnancy, alongside 102 from Iraq, as mothers-to-be are prohibited from serving in war zones. Most pregnancies likely occurred before deployment, though some may have happened on tour. Pregnant personnel are returned to the UK at the earliest opportunity, often on flights reserved for injured troops.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's official residence in Tokyo, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material, was discovered by a staff member. While the amount of cesium is not harmful, the incident has prompted fears about future drone-related threats, especially with major events like the Olympics and G7 summit approaching. Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga emphasized the need for stricter regulations on drone operations. The discovery coincided with a court's approval to restart two nuclear reactors, a decision unpopular among many Japanese citizens due to safety concerns following the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Japanese law currently lacks drone flight restrictions over most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Prime Minister Abe was abroad during the incident.

A security guard from Zhejiang Province, China, named Lu Xincai, has gained national admiration for his devotion to caring for his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease. To ensure her safety and prevent her from getting lost, Lu takes her to work with him on the back of his motorbike every day. He ties a sash around both of their waists to secure her during the one-hour, four-kilometer ride. With his wife working in another city and his son still in school, Lu assumes full responsibility for his mother’s care, especially after his father’s passing. His employer, a bank, provides his mother with a room, and Lu frequently checks on her during work. He feels a deep sense of duty to care for her, as she once cared for him, stating, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple." Lu’s actions reflect his commitment to ensuring his mother’s well-being while balancing his work responsibilities.

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, largely driven by rising rates among women. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defines heavy drinking as more than one drink per day for women and two for men over a month, while binge drinking is four or more drinks for women and five or more for men in a single occasion. Women's binge drinking rates rose significantly faster than men's over the decade studied, with notable increases in places like Santa Clara County, California. Social norms changing to make it more acceptable for women to drink like men, economic factors such as cheaper alcohol in real dollars, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies contributed to these trends. Despite more binge and heavy drinking, the percentage of people drinking any alcohol has remained stable. The study highlights significant health and economic consequences, including 88,600 alcohol-related deaths in 2010 and costs of excessive drinking exceeding $220 billion annually.

Doctors are performing caesarean sections too frequently, putting women and babies at risk, according to UN officials. The procedure should only be done when medically necessary due to risks like infections and death. In England, over a quarter of births involve caesareans, up from the early 1990s, with some women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. The World Health Organisation (WHO) suggests the rate should be 10-15%, warning of significant complications and costs. A planned caesarean costs the NHS £2,369, compared to £1,665 for a natural birth. Current NHS guidelines allow caesareans for anxious women, but the WHO criticizes this, stating doctors underestimate risks, with research showing one in ten cause infections.

A 44-year-old woman named Michelle Filkins was arrested for allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling or giving away the homeowners' belongings in a yard sale. Filkins, from West Wareham, faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The homeowner, Mark Conklin, discovered her in his $800,000 summer home on April 17. When confronted, Filkins falsely claimed ownership of the house and fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket at the property. Filkins was arrested later that day after attempting to re-enter the home. Items reported missing include deck chairs, a Weber grill, lamps, and a painting. Authorities are urging anyone who received items from the home to return them and have assured buyers they will be assisted in seeking restitution. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with her after being handed into Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border. Realizing the phone was unlocked, officers humorously posted selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the station on Bella’s Facebook page, using puns and jokes to grab her attention. The posts, which included captions like “you should probably put a password on your phone,” quickly gained traction among Bella’s friends, who praised the police for their creativity. Bella, who lost her phone at a friend’s birthday party, only realized it was missing the next morning. When she arrived at the station to retrieve it, officers recognized her from her Facebook page and humorously handed it back. Police even joked about the phone being in a holding “cell” and replying to texts from her friends. Bella, who found the situation amusing, has since added a password to her phone and expressed gratitude to the officers for their humor and diligence.

A five-day-old baby hippo was tragically killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, eastern South Africa. The calf was hurled into the air and dragged along the water's surface during the violent brawl. Its mother, who had stayed with her herd to avoid the fight, watched helplessly as one of the males grabbed the calf with its jaws, possibly out of play, jealousy, or aggression. Despite her attempts to intervene, the mother was unable to save her calf, which succumbed to its injuries hours later. Stacey Farrell, a tour operator, witnessed the event and noted the mother’s desperate efforts to protect her calf from other hippos earlier in the day.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of Britain's most expensive areas, is on sale for £575,000, significantly cheaper than neighboring homes. However, the property has only three years left on its lease, making the effective cost £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, equivalent to the area's rental rates. While the price seems like a bargain, the flat requires extensive modernization and lease extension negotiations with the current freeholder, likely the Welcome Trust. Extending the lease to 90 years could cost between £3.35 million and £4.5 million, potentially raising the property's value to over £6 million if renovated. 

Located in the exclusive Egerton Place, the "unmodernized" maisonette spans 1,990 sq/ft, with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. A larger, similarly short-lease maisonette in the same area is priced at £595,000. Estate agents describe the sale as a rare opportunity, attracting interest from locals, developers, and end users. However, experts warn that while the initial price is low, lease extension costs could be substantial, making it a risky investment. This situation highlights the importance of checking lease terms before purchasing property.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage on Friday that impacted point-of-sale registers at 8,000 stores across the U.S. and Canada, leading to free drinks and baked goods being given away to customers. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, disrupted credit card transactions and sales, though some stores continued accepting cash. Many locations closed early to avoid further losses, while excited customers shared their free beverage experiences on social media. Starbucks resolved the issue overnight, allowing stores to resume normal operations on Saturday. The outage also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. This technical glitch occurred just a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are reportedly undergoing training in rural areas of west Wales, including locations in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Detective Constable Gareth Jones revealed that those involved often participate in seemingly ordinary community activities but have underlying motives. He emphasized that terrorism is not confined to large cities, with incidents in Wales dating back to 1998, when hate preacher Abu Hamza allegedly sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons. Other notable cases include the 7/7 bombers training in north Wales and a 2010 plot involving a Cardiff-based group inspired by al-Qaeda. Additionally, Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied at a now-closed Islamic institute in Wales. DC Jones stressed the importance of community intelligence in countering such threats.

A rare Omura's whale, a species once feared extinct, was found washed up on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia, following Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. Initially difficult to identify, DNA profiling confirmed the 5.68-meter juvenile female as an Omura's whale. Environment Minister Albert Jacob highlighted the significance of the discovery for scientific research, as the species, first described in 2003, is poorly understood and typically found in tropical and subtropical waters such as Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body, 53 vertebrae, and unique skeletal features. The carcass has been buried, and its skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further study and potential museum display.

The passage discusses the controversial assertion by Cheryl Rios, a Texas businesswoman, that Hillary Clinton should not be president due to the influence of female hormones, which Rios claims could lead to irrational decisions, such as starting an unnecessary war. This perspective is contrasted with historical examples of male leaders, like George W. Bush, whose decisions have also been questioned, potentially due to testosterone. The article highlights that women leaders tend to take fewer unnecessary risks than men and points out the gender bias women face in leadership roles. Despite progress in education and workforce participation, women still encounter significant barriers due to societal biases, which are both overt (e.g., corporate board representation) and covert (e.g., professor evaluations). The article argues that gender equality benefits everyone, improving company performance, family well-being, and societal outcomes. Rios's stance is criticized, particularly since Canada has previously had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, undermining her claim that women shouldn’t lead. The piece concludes by emphasizing the need to challenge gender biases to create a more equitable society.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small," as Winston Churchill, and in the "Harry Potter" films, is auctioning off his extensive antique collection as he downsizes his home. The auction, set for Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, features over 200 items, including a detailed diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a yew longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, paintings, furniture, books, and more. Hardy, 89, an expert on the medieval longbow and military history, expressed sadness over parting with his cherished collection but hopes the new owners will find as much joy in them as he has. Having studied under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis, Hardy has also published books on the longbow and had a distinguished acting career working alongside stars like Laurence Olivier and Judi Dench. Despite retiring from stage acting after a fall, he plans to continue television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a fugitive sought by authorities as a suspect in the murder of his 57-year-old mother, Sandra Shemansky, whose body was found at their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida. Police became alerted after Shemansky missed a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was discovered dead following a well-being check. Investigators determined foul play was involved, though the exact cause of death and murder weapon remain undisclosed. Shemansky, who is on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness and suicide attempts, was reportedly stressed over ongoing divorce proceedings, which neighbors believe may have contributed to the crime. His mother had reportedly prevented him from attending the visitation to avoid further legal trouble, and he was last seen fleeing on foot without supplies or medication. His estranged wife, who filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago, is taking precautions in case he approaches her. Authorities urge anyone with information to contact them.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council bypassed the standard bidding process, citing a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the event in the U.S. for the first time. Although Eugene lost its bid for the 2019 championships to Doha, Qatar, a recent presentation convinced the IAAF of Eugene's capability to successfully host the event. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized the strategic decision, highlighting collaboration among public authorities, private entities, and a supportive public. The 2007 Osaka championships were similarly awarded without a bidding process. This decision aims to expand the sport's global reach by tapping into the U.S. market.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for her role in the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger lured Hassan, whom she met at a London casino, into a honey trap to steal his gambling winnings. She befriended him, gaining his trust and gifts, before orchestrating his death by leaving his flat door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, to enter. They tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home, leaving him with multiple broken bones and drowning in his own blood. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years. Granger was convicted of manslaughter but acquitted of murder. The court described the attack as "pitiless and wicked," motivated by greed and ruthlessness. Granger claimed she acted out of love for Jackson, but the judge noted her deceitful behavior and lack of compassion. Hassan’s family described his death as a tragedy that will haunt them forever.

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea's midfielder, has experienced a significant dip in form during the second half of the season, a trend noted even before his £30million transfer to Chelsea. Despite a strong start, including a near-certainty to break Thierry Henry's Premier League assist record, Fabregas's performance has declined, with only one assist in his last five games and four in 15 appearances in 2015. This slump has raised concerns about his durability and impact, both for Chelsea and Spain, as evidenced by Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland where Fabregas struggled. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is concerned about Fabregas's fatigue but hopes for a resurgence, particularly as Chelsea aims to secure the Premier League title. Fabregas remains a key player for Chelsea, and his potential revival could be crucial in their remaining games against teams he has previously performed well against.

West Ham is negotiating a deal for Jamaican 17-year-old football prospect Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a trial with the club's academy. Beckford, from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from Belgian clubs and is considered a top emerging talent from the Caribbean. Additionally, West Ham has announced affordable season ticket prices starting at £289 as part of their strategy to attract fans to their new 54,000-capacity Olympic Stadium for the 2016-17 season.

A police investigation into a violent assault on huntsman Mike Lane has been dropped after three months, despite substantial evidence, including a video of the incident and a dossier with names and car registration numbers of suspected saboteurs. Lane, who suffered serious injuries including concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss, condemned the decision as "pathetic" and expressed frustration over the lack of progress. The attack occurred on January 24 when around 15 protesters, some armed with iron bars on ropes, confronted 30 riders and hounds from the Tedworth Hunt. Lane was beaten by a masked assailant whose face was captured on video, but police have been unable to identify him. Hunt supporters and witnesses criticized the police for shelving the inquiry, with some alleging rural crimes are overlooked. Wiltshire Police stated the case remains "undetected" pending further evidence, while the Countryside Alliance called for a ban on face coverings to aid prosecutions.

Adam Gadahn, known as Al Qaeda's American mouthpiece, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. A prominent English-language propagandist for Al Qaeda, Gadahn had converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998, eventually becoming a key figure in the group's media efforts. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and supporting Al Qaeda, appearing in numerous threatening videos aimed at the U.S. and its allies. Gadahn criticized U.S. presidents, urged lone-wolf attacks, and played a significant institutional role within Al Qaeda, including advising on media strategy. His death was part of an operation that also killed another U.S. citizen, Ahmed Farouq, and unintentionally resulted in the deaths of hostages, including American Warren Weinstein. Gadahn, who had a Jewish ancestry and rural California upbringing, left a lasting impact through his propagandist activities for Al Qaeda.

Chinese parents are enthusiastic about nurturing child prodigies, as highlighted by the emergence of a new young basketball sensation. A viral video showcases five-year-old Mai Zizhuo's impressive basketball skills, which have garnered widespread admiration across China. Mai has been playing basketball since he was two and a half, displaying remarkable talent by scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. His skills have earned him numerous fans, with many netizens expressing disbelief, curiosity about his background, and even feelings of inadequacy in comparison. Previously, China's most prominent basketball star was Yao Ming, who played in the NBA from 2002 to 2011.

Tom O'Carroll, a former leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to advocate for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation, viewing it as biased and unfair, and supports the creation of a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's involvement with Hacked Off is likely to embarrass the group. PIE had alliances with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which lobbied to lower the age of sexual consent and legalise incest. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals," confirmed his attendance at the February meeting, which was chaired by comedian John Cleese. A Hacked Off spokesman noted the meeting was open to the public.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event, held at the iconic location, featured an androgynous, monochrome collection of ten unisex pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for both day and night. Models paraded through the empty pool and along the break wall, with the ocean as a stunning backdrop. Guests enjoyed food from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria under sunny, unseasonably warm conditions. The show, organized by restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss, drew crowds, including beachgoers and passers-by, who watched from nearby vantage points.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a family day at a safari park in Northern California, where he fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions. He was accompanied by his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about potential matchups with Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, or Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name mistakenly included on an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and terrorism victims. His name appeared on the wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl ahead of Israel's Memorial Day. However, Abu Khdeir's family, particularly his father Hussein Abu Khdeir, objected, stating that his son should not be listed alongside "soldiers of the occupation." Additionally, Almagor, an organization representing terror victims, opposed his inclusion, calling his death a "rogue attack" rather than a terror-related incident. Following complaints, Israel's National Insurance Institute decided to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial. The three suspects in his killing are currently on trial.

A young boy in California, filmed by his father Lionel Hutz, repeatedly tries to use the family cat as a pillow for rest. The cat, initially licking its fur, moves away each time the boy lies on it. After a few attempts, the cat retreats indoors, seemingly annoyed. Later, the boy and cat reconcile, with the child feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves witness Robert Kushner, who lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past as a marijuana dealer. Kushner, 32, is among over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government about alleged police misconduct. He claimed that undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him in 2007. Although the 2007 charges were expunged through a probationary sentence, Kushner faced arrests in 2011 and for a DUI in 2008. The six former police officers are charged with racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping, and drug dealing. Kushner expressed regret over not revealing his past to the school, insisting he has moved past his previous life. Despite the controversy, Kushner is described as a skilled and caring coach. Defense lawyers argue that the case relies on testimonies from unreliable drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province, China, injured six people and caused a massive fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spill was reported. Over 600 firefighters managed to control the fire, with five injured by broken glass. Residents nearby heard the explosion and felt tremors. This plant had a previous explosion in 2013 without casualties. PX plants have historically sparked protests in China due to pollution concerns, including in 2007 when the plant’s original location in Xiamen was changed to its current site following public opposition.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Republic of Ireland Under 21 international, has expressed his refusal to comply with Premier League referees' requests to pull his socks up, citing superstition. Known for wearing his socks low, just above his shinpads, Grealish uses children's-sized shinpads and has no plans to change this habit. He made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, a game he described as tough but was glad to have completed. Grealish appreciates the manager's faith in him and hopes to earn more starts before the season ends. Despite his unique style, he feels confident and supported, stating that he hasn't suffered any shin injuries so far.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Although no longer in a medically induced coma, Bobbi Kristina remains unresponsive, showing no reaction to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not track movement. She has a tracheostomy and has been in this neurological state for nearly three months. While her father, Bobby Brown, claimed she was "awake" and "watching him," and she has been moved out of ICU and started rehabilitation, her long-term quality of life remains uncertain. Her attorney stated she will have a long life but emphasized the rehabilitation process will be extensive, with her future quality of life unknown for years. Family members continue to trust in a miracle, with Cissy Houston expressing sadness over her granddaughter's potential lifelong condition.

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Germany's Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova won 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, following Svetlana Kuznetsova's straight-sets victory over Julia Goerges. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki's powerful play and committed 13 double faults, while Lisicki made 63 unforced errors. Russia needs one more win in Sunday’s matches to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are bracing for more floods and damage as another storm, potentially an east coast low similar to last week's, is predicted to hit the region. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned about the impact on clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 jobs still pending from last week’s 24,196 requests. Heavy rain is expected from Thursday to Saturday, particularly affecting the Hunter region, which was severely impacted last week. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills emphasized the urgency for residents to prepare, as saturated ground and uprooted trees pose significant risks. Meteorologists indicate the storm might not be as severe or prolonged as last week's, but coastal areas in the state’s northeast and southeast Queensland could see intense rainfall and strong winds. The SES is working to complete as many repairs as possible before the storm hits, with over 1,000 personnel deployed, including support from other states. Further rainfall may exacerbate existing flooding in already affected areas.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied claims that she attempted to take her own life after Italian media reported she was hospitalized following an incident at her Milan apartment. Moric, who has over 40,000 Instagram followers, posted photos of her bruising and explained that she collapsed due to low blood pressure and fell, injuring herself. She clarified that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time and that she is recovering at home. Moric expressed shock at the suicide claims, stating she is fine and just needs rest. Italian media also linked her to a past alleged suicide attempt in 2009. Moric was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, a jailed paparazzi king known for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photos, with whom she has a son, Carlos Maria. Corona admitted to unethical behavior during a phone-tapped conversation.

As Kate and William await the birth of their second child, the British public are hoping for a traditional name. A YouGov poll for The Sunday Times reveals "Diana" is the top choice for a girl, favored by 12% of respondents, in honor of William’s late mother, Princess Diana. Other popular names include "Alice" and "Charlotte," each receiving 9% of the vote. For a boy, "James" is the favorite, with "Alexander" as the second choice. The poll of 2,200 people shows a quarter want a girl, while only 3% hope for a brother for Prince George. Many on social media express strong support for naming the baby "Diana." Additionally, 68% of Brits approve of William taking six weeks of paternity leave from his job as a pilot.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack occurred in the city of Khost as the protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied involvement, and no other group has claimed responsibility. The explosion happened around 10 a.m. local time. The report was contributed by CNN staff from Kabul, Hong Kong, and elsewhere.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The Brazilian right-back, who has spent seven successful years at the club, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, could not agree on a new deal. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves rejected a three-year extension, contingent on him playing 60% of matches. She criticized the timing and handling of the negotiations, stating they are now over.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has called for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games for Boca, believes the duo would be a great fit due to their South American-style play and immense talent. He expressed confidence that Boca's iconic La Bombonera stadium would embrace them enthusiastically. Pirlo is regarded as one of the best midfielders globally, while Totti, a Roma legend, is admired for his enduring legacy. Osvaldo feels both players would be loved by Boca fans if they were to make the move.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, fell spectacularly from his horse during a race at Wincanton, resulting in a double somersault that went viral online. Despite the dramatic fall, he sustained only a cut on his nose and returned to his routine, mucking out stables and riding out the next morning. Ferguson expressed feeling lucky and undeterred, acknowledging the humorous banter and increased social media attention he received. Although he joked about a potential gymnastics career due to the somersaults, he remains focused on horse racing.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, showcased his inner Iron Man in an Instagram post, coinciding with the release of *Avengers: Age of Ultron*. The movie, highly anticipated and featuring stars like Robert Downey Jr., premiered at Westfield London. Haskell, dressed as Iron Man, shared the post on Thursday with a message referencing the film. Haskell, who began his career with Wasps in 2002, returned to the club in 2012 after playing for Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders. Since rejoining Wasps, he has made over 100 appearances and earned 57 England caps. His career has seen him play in France, Japan, and New Zealand before finding success back in England.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide-leg trousers as a key trend for SS15, offering a refreshing alternative to skinny jeans. This style, available in denim, cropped, printed, or striped variations, has roots in 1970s fashion and has reappeared on recent runways, including Gucci and Celine. Styling tips emphasize proportion, suggesting pairing wide-leg trousers with simple tops and high-heeled shoes to elongate the legs, especially for shorter individuals. Denim is highlighted as an accessible entry point for the trend, with brands like Topshop offering affordable options. For dressier occasions, Celine and Stella McCartney provide sophisticated styles. The trend is versatile, suitable for various occasions, and can be embraced regardless of weather. Poppy Delevingne and Louise Redknapp are cited as style inspirations. For more details and shopping options, readers are directed to astylealbum.com.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with screening the film *American Sniper* despite objections from some students who believed the movie negatively depicted the Iraq War and Middle Eastern people. Over 200 students signed a petition to cancel the screening, but a counter-petition supported showing the film, emphasizing freedom of expression. The university's vice president for student life, E. Royster Harper, stated that canceling the film was a mistake and inconsistent with the institution's values. The movie, starring Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL, will be shown as part of a student social event series called UMix. For those uninterested in *American Sniper*, UMix will screen *Paddington*. The decision to reinstate the film was praised by Michigan's head football coach, Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly set fire to a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3 by igniting aerosol spray with a lighter. The quokka, a small marsupial native to the region, survived but suffered singed fur. The men were questioned by detectives, evicted from the island, and charged with animal cruelty. They are set to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, which are about the size of a domestic cat, are commonly found on Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer who performed at New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, saw herself dance for the first time after filmmakers compiled video footage of her performances from "soundies," or early music videos. Despite losing her photographs and memorabilia over the years, Barker was thrilled to view the footage at her nursing home, expressing delight at finally seeing her past performances.

The passage discusses the decline of car washing as a personal activity in Britain, once a common Sunday routine. New figures reveal that a third of men have never washed their own car, and three-quarters of women have never done so either, with many preferring professional car washes. A survey of 1,100 adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that only 12% of men who wash their cars do so regularly, and only 5% involve their children in the task for pocket money. Factors contributing to this decline include shops opening on Sundays, more televised football, the rise of hand car washes, and larger vehicles being harder to clean. However, car owners are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, such as Easter, though some do it just as an excuse to leave the house. Car washing frequency varies by city, with Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield leading, and Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh lagging. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are most likely to wash their cars, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners are least likely. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley notes the tradition has waned due to busier lifestyles, larger cars, and affordable professional alternatives.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's significant influence since his arrival at Liverpool in 2008, acknowledging him as one of the best players in the world and a symbol of the club. Gerrard, Liverpool's captain, is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead the team to the final against Arsenal before departing for LA Galaxy. Skrtel, who has become a key player in Liverpool's defense, credits Gerrard with helping him settle at the club. Although Gerrard's departure will leave a void, Skrtel believes Liverpool has potential replacements who can step up with the right support. Both players may return to the lineup for the Villa match after serving bans.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National, adding another memorable moment to his legendary career. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus aced the 130-yard fourth hole, delighting the crowd. Although it was his first hole-in-one at Augusta, Nicklaus' achievement was overshadowed by Camilo Villegas, who scored two aces that day. Villegas, however, lost the title to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, the youngest to win a green jacket in 1963 and a six-time Masters champion, is one of five golfers to achieve the career grand slam.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve sheriff's deputy from Oklahoma, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for the fatal shooting of Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation. Bates claims he accidentally shot Harris with his gun when he intended to use a Taser. The judge allowed Bates to take a family vacation to the Bahamas, which Harris's family criticized as showing "apathy" toward Eric's death. Bates's lawyers argue he had proper training, despite claims from Harris’s family lawyer that he was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and his friendship with the sheriff. Two deputies involved in Harris’s arrest were reassigned due to threats. Bates’s preliminary hearing is set for July 2, where his legal team anticipates addressing the case in court rather than through media reports.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the bout, McGregor unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, symbolizing ferocity, and shared it on Instagram. The Irish fighter, known as "The Notorious," already has a chest tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart. McGregor claims he has more motivation to win the title than Aldo, who is making his eighth title defense. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and held it in front of 5,000 fans, further fueling their tense rivalry. With less than three months until the fight, McGregor aims to legitimize his ambitions by winning the championship.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, with critics arguing he was glorifying binge drinking and reinforcing stereotypes linking masculinity to heavy drinking. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, described the incident as "problematic," stating it promoted a culture focused on drinking excessively rather than socializing. Abbott downed the beer in six seconds to cheers from onlookers. While Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott's actions, emphasizing his fitness and discipline, others, including opposition leader Bill Shorten, made light of the incident. Critics argued that as a leader, Abbott should model responsible drinking habits rather than perpetuating harmful stereotypes about being a "true blue Aussie bloke." Dr. Robert noted the broader issue included media reactions and highlighted shifting societal attitudes toward binge drinking. Abbott also delivered a speech at the event, joking about rugby and Australian rules football, further endearing himself to the crowd.

Indiana has experienced a significant rise in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County, linked primarily to intravenous drug use of the painkiller Opana. This outbreak prompted Governor Mike Pence to approve a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26 to curb the spread. Since then, 5,322 clean syringes have been distributed, and 1,400 used ones returned. Health officials anticipate further case increases as testing expands, pressuring Pence to extend the program beyond April 25. A decision is expected early next week. 

The program has gained traction, particularly through a mobile unit fostering trust among drug users. However, Pence, who opposes needle exchanges as anti-drug policy, faces legislative uncertainty regarding similar programs in other counties. A bill allowing 23 high-risk counties to establish exchanges passed the House but requires Senate approval. Critics worry needle exchanges may encourage drug use, while advocates argue they are effective harm-reduction strategies. Funding remains an issue, as federal bans on public financing for such programs persist, and Pence's order did not allocate state funds, raising concerns about long-term sustainability.

An Arsenal-obsessed fan tested his girlfriend, Saskia, on her knowledge of the football club, grading her with an 87% score (43.5/50). He jokingly told her she wouldn't be dumped due to her "A grade." The test, resembling a school exam, included multiple-choice questions, player identification, and creative responses. Saskia humorously answered some questions, like why Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard, earning bonus points for calling Hazard a "p***k." Despite some errors, she impressed her boyfriend and fellow Arsenal fans on social media, with some calling her "proper gf material." While many found the test amusing and praised the boyfriend, others criticized him for taking it too far. The boyfriend's feedback included corrections in capital letters and an angry face for wrong answers, though it was likely all in jest.

An improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia, albeit a month later than expected, to address two new strains: influenza A (H3N2) and influenza B (B/Phuket). These strains caused a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States due to a mismatch with the previous vaccine. The updated vaccine, which also protects against H1N1, is expected to be a better match for circulating strains globally. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, will have access to free government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, emphasized the importance of vaccination for everyone, not just high-risk individuals, as it protects both individuals and those around them. He urged people to book their flu shots despite the delayed stock arrival. The same vaccine will be used in the upcoming northern winter.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing challenges due to a negative critique in National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts that could impact the management of the historic site. This comes as they mark the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination. Illinois, known as the "Land of Lincoln," is in a financial crisis, and Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb, intending to merge it with another department. The magazine described the tomb as having "all the historical character of an office lobby," and historian Adam Goodheart called it "a disappointment," criticizing its art deco style. Despite recent repairs and renovations costing over $2.5 million, which have left the tomb in "excellent physical condition," concerns remain about reduced hours, staffing cuts, and potential further budget reductions. Supporters of the site, including volunteer tour guides, argue that the critique is unfair. The tomb, originally designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated in 1874, has undergone multiple reconstructions and features a circular structure with black and tan marble, bronze trim, and access to Lincoln’s burial chamber. While some visitors and officials disagree with the critique, uncertainty looms over the future management of this significant historical site.

The passage discusses the resurgence of various 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, some of which are met with mixed reactions. Key trends mentioned include:

1. **Bucket Hats**: Originally used by fishermen, they became popular in the '90s and early 2000s and are now seen on celebrities like Rihanna.
2. **Camouflage Print**: Popularized by bands like Destiny's Child, it's now seen on modern celebrities like Jourdan Dunn.
3. **Extreme Fashion**: Trends like double denim and bold prints were widespread in the '90s and are now sported by stars like Kylie Jenner.
4. **Ugg Boots**: These were a celebrity favorite in the 2000s and remain popular for their comfort, as seen on Kristen Bell.
5. **Daisy Dukes**: Popularized by Jessica Simpson, these tiny denim shorts are still worn by celebrities like Miley Cyrus.
6. **Juicy Couture Tracksuits**: A staple in the early 2000s for stars like Paris Hilton and Britney Spears, they remain trendy with celebrities like Nicki Minaj.
7. **Coloured Sunglasses**: Once favored by '90s pop stars, they have been updated with mirrored finishes and are worn by Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner.
8. **Corsets as Outfits**: Popularized as outerwear by Victoria Beckham, corsets are now incorporated into dresses by stars like Selena Gomez.
9. **Harem Trousers**: Once favored by Kim Kardashian, they are still worn by supermodels like Elle Macpherson.

The article reflects on these trends with a mix of nostalgia and critique, questioning whether some should be left in the past.

The passage highlights various trending stories from the week. In New York, four rainbows appeared after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes, now under government scrutiny, is becoming less common. Robert Downey Jr. expressed frustration during a UK interview, while the Kardashians sparked another trend: lip plumping inspired by Kylie Jenner. A 102-year-old woman revisited her past through old films, and a controversial promposal led to accusations of racism. Ewan McGregor’s role as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast" and Johnny Depp's transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer gained social media attention. Unique pregnancy announcements and a military dad’s photobomb also made headlines.

The passage highlights significant achievements at the Miami Open, focusing on Serena Williams and Andy Murray. Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory with a cake after defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets (7-6, 1-6, 6-3) to reach the semi-finals. Her potential match against sister Venus Williams was thwarted by Venus's loss to Carla Suarez Navarro. Serena, the world No. 1, aims to excel in this near-hometown event and is set to face Simona Halep, who advanced after defeating Sloane Stephens. Earlier, Andy Murray marked his 500th win with a celebratory cake. Serena's match was a revenge win against Lisicki, who had beaten her at Wimbledon 2013.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent Pakistani advocate for free speech, human rights, and progressive values, was killed in Karachi after hosting a discussion on the sensitive topic of enforced disappearances in Baluchistan. Her second-floor cafe, The Second Floor (T2F), was a vibrant hub for open dialogue, art, and activism, attracting young Pakistanis and fostering secular thought. Despite facing threats and operating in a climate hostile to free expression, Mahmud remained fearless in challenging societal norms and amplifying marginalized voices. Her murder, carried out by unidentified gunmen, shocked the nation and highlighted the dangers of dissent in Pakistan. Friends and admirers mourned her as a symbol of courage, love, and tolerance, with many praising her unwavering commitment to justice and freedom of thought. The artistic and intellectual legacy of T2F, reflected in its eclectic decor and bold discussions, underscored Mahmud's enduring impact on Pakistan's progressive community.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer, is among thousands of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) who fled to Indian Kashmir during the partition of India nearly 70 years ago. Despite living in India for decades, Ram and others like him have been denied citizenship rights, including the ability to own property, vote in state elections, or work in state government, due to disputes over Kashmir's status and fears of upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. Classified as refugees, most WPRs have never visited Pakistan and live in poverty, with limited opportunities for education and employment. However, hope for change has arisen after the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, won a share of power in Kashmir's state government. The BJP has pledged to address the WPRs' plight by granting them state-subject rights, potentially allowing them to integrate fully. Veteran activist Labha Ram Gandhi warns that the community is prepared to protest if their demands are ignored. While Kashmir remains prosperous and conflicted, the WPRs continue to live as second-class citizens, with many calling for urgent reforms to improve their conditions.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is contemplating a move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who have reportedly offered £4 million for the Japan international. Although Chelsea intends to loan Muto to their partner club Vitesse Arnhem for the next season, the 22-year-old is focused on joining a team where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Muto expressed the need to carefully consider his options, emphasizing the importance of finding a suitable team that aligns with his development goals. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut, praised Muto's speed, intelligence, confidence, and unique qualities, suggesting he could succeed at Chelsea. Chelsea's interest in Muto aligns with their recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, highlighting the role of commercial interests in their transfer policy. Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho acknowledged awareness of Muto but refrained from commenting extensively, noting the balance between financial considerations and acquiring talented players.

The passage criticizes England's policy of not selecting rugby players based overseas, contrasting it with Australia's decision to drop this rule. Australia's change allows them to pick top talents like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, who excel for Toulon, for the World Cup. The author argues that England's coach, Stuart Lancaster, should have the freedom to select the best players regardless of location, emphasizing that other top teams, like South Africa and Wales, do so. Players such as Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon have improved significantly by moving to clubs like Toulon, proving that playing overseas can enhance performance. The piece insists that for England to succeed in the upcoming home World Cup, they must prioritize picking the best squad, avoiding regrets later. It concludes by urging England to follow Australia's example and end this "ridiculous" restriction, ensuring the national team has the strongest possible lineup.

The passage discusses the development of FireChat, an app enabling off-the-grid communication without the internet or mobile signals, leveraging wireless mesh networks via features like Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF). To enhance these networks, Open Garden created Greenstone, an egg-shaped device acting as a beacon to boost message transmission within wireless mesh networks. FireChat, downloaded over five million times, allows users to communicate in 'chatrooms' via 'Everyone' (global) or 'Nearby' (local Bluetooth/Wi-Fi range) options. It ensures secure and anonymous messaging, immune to hacking due to no internet reliance. However, message range is limited to about 200 feet, a gap Greenstone aims to address. Currently, Greenstone works only with FireChat at a 20-foot range, holding up to 1,000 messages and lasting a year on battery. Open Garden envisions its use in scenarios like festivals or protests, and is partnering with manufacturers for broader deployment.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is advocating for body positivity by embracing the word "fat" as a neutral and honest descriptor of her physique. In a TED talk, she explained that terms like "fat," "short," and "wife" are simply factual descriptions and shouldn't carry negative connotations, particularly challenging the idea that "fat" equates to "ugly." Despite societal programming that often views being fat as undesirable, Bustle argues that size discrimination has risen by 66% over 30 years, with girls aged 11-17 often wishing to be thinner. However, studies suggest that exposure to body diversity fosters acceptance and preference for different body types. Through her burlesque performances, Bustle showcases her "fat" body in a glamorous, empowering way, helping to reshape perceptions. Inspired by another performer, Beelzebabe, Bustle emphasizes that diverse body types challenge societal norms of desirability. Initially nervous about her first performance in 2012, she now feels empowered and encourages others to find a "courage reference" to boost self-esteem. Despite some negative comments online, her TED talk, released on YouTube in 2014, has garnered nearly 38,000 views and overwhelmingly positive feedback, including stories of personal impact. Bustle believes that progress in body positivity is being made.

The passage highlights Theo Walcott's limited playing time for Arsenal this season, often being on the bench. Walcott participated in a Lanvin photoshoot with teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, along with model Olga Sherer, as part of Arsenal's partnership with the fashion house. Despite being named on the substitutes' bench for 17 of 33 Premier League games, Walcott has seen minimal action, with his last start dating back to March 14. He briefly came on during Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea and hopes to start in the upcoming match against Hull. Arsenal’s first-team players will also wear Lanvin attire for the FA Cup final on May 30.

A collection of props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker's Cinovation Studio will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection, valued at an estimated $746,100, includes over 400 items from more than 50 productions spanning Baker's 30-year career. Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from *Men in Black* ($40,000), the Grinch costume from *How the Grinch Stole Christmas* ($8,000), and the Two-Face mask from *Batman Forever* ($1,500). Other highlights include pieces from *Gremlins 2*, *Planet of the Apes*, *Batman & Robin*, *Harry and the Hendersons*, and Michael Jackson’s *Moonwalker*. Brandon Alinger of Prop Store emphasized the auction’s significance for collectors and fans, offering a chance to own iconic pieces of Hollywood history. Items are expected to fetch high prices, with some potentially exceeding their listed values.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy described as daring, outgoing, and determined, tragically died after falling 164 feet in the French Alps while skiing with his family. The youngster, from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales, became separated from his mother after leaving the piste to head into woodland, possibly trying to reach the resort he spotted through the trees. His family, who were on a ski holiday in Flaine, were devastated, describing him as an adorable, caring boy who brought laughter and love. Carwyn’s mother desperately searched for him, but his body was later found after police followed his footprints in the snow. The tragedy has left his family and community heartbroken, with tributes pouring in from friends, classmates, and teachers. Carwyn, a skilled skier and snowboarder since age three, was remembered as a lively and likeable child who loved the mountains and his family’s farm. His body is set to be repatriated as the family remains in the Alps.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at the age of 13 due to pressure to be a 'size zero' and bullying about her weight. She survived on just one piece of fruit a day, hid food, and lied to her mother about eating. Her dramatic weight loss led to her collapse and hospitalization, where she was placed on a heart monitor. Laura's body began to shut down, and her heart rate slowed dangerously. After being discharged, she received support from eating disorder organizations and mental health services. Now recovered, Laura has reached the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes body positivity and confidence for young girls, moving away from size zero stereotypes. Anorexia is a serious mental health condition often driven by anxiety about body shape or weight, and it commonly affects women around ages 16 or 17.

Liverpool fans expressed their desire for Raheem Sterling to stay with the club during the unveiling of the new home kit at Anfield. The kit, designed by New Balance under a record £300million deal, replaces Warrior as Liverpool's supplier. Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet showcased the new strip, themed "Hold Nothing Back," to fans in the Centenary Stand. Despite Sterling's recent rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract and his admission of being flattered by Arsenal's interest, Liverpool insists he will not leave this summer. Sterling praised the fans, while Sturridge emphasized the importance of winning the FA Cup. The kit features white branding and a new collar style, with tributes to the Hillsborough disaster. Legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush attended the launch, and Steven Gerrard’s hope for an FA Cup final appearance remains alive.

The passage discusses the creation of the largest high-definition map of dark matter, produced by researchers at the University of Manchester. This map is the first in a series that aims to provide a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky, aiding in the study of galaxy formation. The map, which covers 0.4% of the sky, uses color coding (red for more dark matter, blue for less) and was constructed using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile. The project, part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES), seeks to map 12.5% of the sky by 2018.

Dark matter, which makes up about 80% of the universe's matter, is invisible and does not interact with light but exerts gravitational effects. The survey detects dark matter indirectly by observing its gravitational lensing effects on galaxies. The map's analysis will help probe dark energy, responsible for the universe's accelerated expansion. The team analyzed 130 million galaxy images, requiring significant computational power, and the survey has already revealed large filaments of matter where galaxies form, supporting current cosmological theories. The DES aims to improve understanding of the interplay between dark matter and visible matter, ultimately revealing more about dark energy.

Manchester United have intensified their pursuit of PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old star Memphis Depay by making an official approach. PSV confirmed the move, with Man United's manager Louis van Gaal, who previously included Depay in Holland's 2014 World Cup squad, keen to sign him this summer. Premier League rivals Tottenham had shown interest last summer, but their £15 million bid was rejected. Now, United appear to be leading the race despite competition from clubs like Paris Saint-Germain. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helped PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. Pacy and skilled, Depay is compared to Arjen Robben by PSV's manager Phillip Cocu, while scout Ed van Steijn claims Depay surpasses a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay, who began his career at a Dutch amateur club, has over 100 appearances for PSV and was nominated for the 'Best Young Player' award at the 2014 World Cup. Despite his talent, he is still learning and can occasionally make mistakes.

Chelsea secured a commanding 3-1 lead in the first leg of their youth cup match against Manchester City's young side. Tammy Abraham scored a double in the first half, including a fierce drive into the top corner, to put Chelsea ahead. Dominic Solanke added a late third goal to solidify the scoreline. Chelsea's defense, led by Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, effectively neutralized City's threats, while the midfield, commanded by Charlie Colkett, dominated the game. Manchester City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored the equalizer, but they struggled to maintain momentum, with several players like Bersant Celina and Manu Garcia being largely ineffective. Abraham's injury in the 67th minute was a concern for Chelsea, but overall, they showcased a strong performance heading back to West London.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated that people are born with a sexual preference but believes that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He argued that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and that decisions about marriage definitions should be left to state legislatures rather than courts. Despite his personal beliefs, Rubio said he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, emphasizing respect for their choices. He also noted that while he opposes divorce due to his Catholic beliefs, he would continue to love someone who is divorced. Rubio has received significant financial backing for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado, 27, from Spain, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, from Latvia, are an adventurous couple who quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on an open-ended, budget-friendly cycling journey around the world. With no set plans or agenda, they aim to "discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time." Over the past year, they have traveled nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, including France, Spain, Italy, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, relying on free accommodation such as camping (161 nights), Couchsurfing (66 nights), and Warmshowers (44 nights). Their daily living expenses average less than three euros per person, primarily spent on food like pasta, bread, rice, and seasonal produce, supplemented by wild fruits, dumpster diving, and the kindness of strangers. They cycle with 130 kg of gear and maintain a minimalist lifestyle, taking time to appreciate stunning landscapes and cultural experiences. After crossing from Europe into Asia, they plan to continue through the Pacific and cycle the length of the Americas, expecting to remain on the road for several more years.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 is suing James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, over alleged racist slurs printed on photo booth snapshots from their wedding. The slur, "poor n***** party," was discovered months later when the bride's sister informed the family, delaying the news to avoid ruining the wedding day. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, claims Evans did not apologize and responded dismissively, telling them to "sue" him. Frustrated by his lack of response, they filed a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, accusing the company of negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the allegations, arguing there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption and stating the couple showed no signs of distress. The couple, who held their wedding at the Bell Tower in Houston, seeks an apology rather than financial compensation. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if unresolved.

Mike Brown, the England full-back, is adopting a cautious approach to his recovery from a recent concussion, unsure of his return date after missing Harlequins' match against Saracens. He emphasizes the importance of not rushing back, citing examples like George North, who has been advised not to play again this season after multiple concussions, and Johnny Sexton, who was sidelined for 12 weeks. Brown suffered a concussion during England's victory over Italy and decided not to play against Ireland after recognizing symptoms like headaches. Increased awareness from World Rugby’s online modules helped him understand the dangers of concussions, both short and long-term. Brown highlights the importance of honesty and education around concussion risks, advocating for teammates to prioritize health over play. He was speaking at the launch of Land Rover’s ‘We Deal in Real’ campaign, which celebrates grassroots rugby.

Smartphone use and technological connectivity may be contributing to a decline in sexual frequency among couples, according to Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University. His research, published in the book *Sex by Numbers*, shows that the average heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Possible factors for this decline include the erosion of boundaries between work and private life, increased busyness, and the rise of solo living. Professor Spiegelhalter suggests that constant connectivity, such as checking emails, leaves less quiet, uninterrupted time for relationships. Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, adds that competing demands on time and constant connection reduce the prioritization of intimacy with partners.

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly prized in China and known for commanding prices up to £1.2 million, have seen a dramatic decline in popularity. Previously used as status symbols and gifts to influence officials, the breed's value has plummeted due to China's anti-corruption crackdown, which curbed the gifting of such expensive items. Additionally, urban restrictions on owning dogs over 50 kg have further diminished their appeal. The market collapse has led to mastiffs being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skin for leather. Many of these dogs are now victims of theft, abandonment, or being offloaded by breeders due to a surplus of poor-quality specimens caused by excessive cross-breeding. Animal welfare workers have rescued mastiffs from cruel conditions en route to slaughter, but hundreds more are believed to face similar fates. The breed, originally used for herding in Tibet, is ill-suited to city living, further contributing to their declining popularity. At their peak in 2005, Tibetan mastiffs were considered status symbols, with one dog selling for £1.2 million as recently as 13 months ago.
