Despite interest from Qatari and Chinese groups since the club's move to London Stadium, Sullivan stated last year that only a minority share might be sold to clear debts, with ownership intended to pass to their children.

The passage summarizes the highlights of an awards ceremony that differed from traditional award shows like the Oscars, featuring fan-voted categories such as best kiss and best shirtless performance. "The Fault in Our Stars" was the night's big winner, earning best movie, while its star Shailene Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for his role in "American Sniper," and Channing Tatum and Meryl Streep took home awards for comedic performance and best villain, respectively. Other notable winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, and Seth Rogen. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his children, and Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, presented by the "Avengers" cast. The ceremony also served as a promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters like "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and "Ultron."

Smith, a 21-year-old forward, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season. Having debuted for Aberdeen in 2012, he has scored four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren manager Jack Ross praised Smith as a strong acquisition, highlighting his maturity and attacking potential. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council has announced that warmer weather allows its Jetpatcher machines to begin repairing potholes, with a target of fixing 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will address drainage system damage caused by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, workers on EnQuest's Thistle platform, located 125 miles northeast of Shetland, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework during shutdown activities. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes, a Wood Group contractor, claimed that he and his colleagues worked without proper personal protective equipment (PPE), as it was assumed the area was clear. A health and safety manager reportedly halted work two-thirds of the way through the trip after detecting radiation. Innes stated that, although the radiation levels were not expected to cause long-term harm, the workers now face cancer fears and are undergoing blood tests. He accused EnQuest of failing in its duty of care. EnQuest stated that the radiation exposure was less than 1% of the reportable threshold and that additional precautionary measures were implemented post-incident. Wood Group emphasized its commitment to employee safety, conducting medical assessments and supporting a joint investigation with EnQuest. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) confirmed awareness of the incident but noted it was not reportable under current regulations, so no investigation was conducted. The Unite union criticized the handling of the incident, stressing the need for transparency to improve offshore safety. Innes has struggled to find work since raising concerns.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a stolen Indian sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted to trafficking stolen antiquities. The theft likely occurred from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. Following a 2012 court case against the dealer and discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), ACM decided to return the sculpture after receiving an official request from the ASI in May. While there is no definitive proof of the theft, the museum acted on the dealer's confession of dealing in looted artifacts. The ACM also plans to seek legal compensation for the fraud, despite purchasing 30 objects from the dealer, with no others confirmed stolen. The ASI reviewed all items.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicenter in Garfagnana. The tremor, which occurred at 15:48 local time, was felt as far as Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena, causing phone lines and power outages in the Garfagnana area. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy, prone to earthquakes, experienced aftershocks and is still recovering from the 2009 L'Aquila quake that killed nearly 300 people. The latest quake, described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow," came unexpectedly. The 2009 disaster led to the conviction of six scientists and an official for providing misleading reassurances before the deadly event. This highlights the challenges of earthquake prediction and risk communication in the region.

Austin Grant from Sheffield initially doubted the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate for growing fruit but has now seen successful results. On 8 September 2016, he expressed his joy at the fruit remaining attached to the plant and not yet being ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the new GTA V PC version until 24 March, postponing from the original date of 27 January. The delay is attributed to additional testing and polishing time needed to ensure the game's quality. Although the delay might disappoint fans, Rockstar assures that the extra time will be worthwhile. On a positive note, eagerly-awaited online heists will be available on consoles prior to the PC release. The PC version promises enhanced detail, with Los Santos and Blaine County presented in 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor setups. Minimum PC specifications for running the game have been released. GTA V originally launched on 17 September 2013 and became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, earning $1 billion in just three days.

Rose Wylie, a 76-year-old artist, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for her work *Squint (19)* at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. This marked her first win after being shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times. Judge Ansel Krut described the painting as "quite extraordinary" yet challenging to view, noting its technical subtlety and emotional depth. The painting depicts a leper squint, holes in medieval churches allowing "undesirables" to observe services, and is part of a series Wylie has been working on, though it is relatively small at 7ft in height. Wylie entered it because she was familiar with the piece and thought it a good fit for the competition. She plans to spend the prize money on art supplies like canvas and high-quality paints. Krut likened the painting to a tone poem, revealing its depth over time and praising its empathetic subject matter. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is a prestigious biennial award with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, the current patron, won the junior title in 1961.

The passage reports on coordinated attacks against the offices of two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, in Istanbul. Four masked assailants targeted the Yeni Safak building, starting a fire that was quickly extinguished. Both buildings suffered shattered windows from gunfire, with spent bullet casings found at the scenes. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously early on Thursday, despite the offices being 20km apart. Police have cordoned off the areas and are searching for the attackers, who remain unidentified as no group has claimed responsibility. The newspapers support President Recep Tayyip

A 24-year-old player, previously with the Stags and on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, will join Marcus Bignot's team, Grimsby Town (the Mariners), on a free transfer starting 1 January, marking Bignot's first signing for the club.

The passage discusses Arsène Wenger's response to being linked with the England managerial job, currently held on an interim basis by Gareth Southgate. Wenger emphasizes his focus on his role at Arsenal and praises Southgate’s competence, urging him to prove his capability in upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain. Wenger also addresses Arsenal matters, confirming Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract despite transfer speculation, and mentions Aaron Ramsey’s injury absence.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police, in collaboration with the Health and Safety Executive, are conducting an investigation, with the company fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay on freight vessels serving the Northern Isles. The RMT union had raised concerns that some crew members on the freight boats Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink, were paid less than £4 an hour. Seatruck claimed the national minimum wage did not apply to the largely non-UK crew. Serco Northlink had offered to address the pay gap but was rebuffed by Seatruck. Under the new charter, which starts next month pending final details, contracted services will return to Serco Northlink, ensuring all crew are paid at least the minimum wage. The Scottish government subsidizes this critical ferry route, operated by Serco Northlink since 2012 under a £243m contract.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on 14 May following an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57. The couple had been in a relationship for years but were experiencing difficulties. On 7 May, after drinking heavily at a holiday park bar, a confrontation occurred between Mr. Dickie and Mr. Mitchell, which was broken up by bystanders. Jamie Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and both he and his mother admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police about the events. They claimed Mr. Dickie had pushed Mrs. Mitchell, who pushed him back, but later Mitchell stated he had tried to separate them, leading to what he called a "tragic accident." Sentencing is scheduled for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a renowned British songwriter, passed away at the age of 66 in London after a brief battle with cancer. Known for his significant contributions to music, Temperton wrote hits like "Off The Wall," "Baby Be Mine," and "Boogie Nights." His songwriting career took off after joining the disco group Heatwave, leading to collaborations with Michael Jackson on albums "Off The Wall" and "Thriller," the latter becoming the best-selling album in U.S. history. Temperton's work also garnered him a Grammy and two Oscar nominations. Despite his success, he maintained a low profile, earning the nickname "The Invisible Man." Tributes poured in from artists like Nile Rodgers, Mark Ronson, and Chaka Khan, acknowledging his impact on music. A private funeral has taken place, and his family requests privacy.

Researchers, including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, have discovered over 450 ancient geometrical earthworks, or "geoglyphs," in Brazil's western Amazon. These ditched enclosures, up to 2,000 years old, were hidden by rainforest until recent deforestation revealed them. The team, which includes researchers from the UK and Brazil, suggests these structures were likely used sporadically as ritual sites rather than for defense or permanent settlement, based on the lack of artifacts and their layout. Unlike other ritual sites globally, the geoglyphs were built within taller vegetation and not visible above the forest canopy, according to Dr Loader’s soil analysis. The findings challenge the idea that pre-European Amazonian forests were pristine, showing instead that humans actively managed the environment by cultivating useful tree species, creating a "prehistoric supermarket." This ancient agroforestry may still influence the biodiversity of the region's forests today.

Nick Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian tennis player ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey in a swift 53-minute match, advancing to the second round with a 6-4, 6-4 win. Despite his recent victory at the Japan Open and his pursuit of a top 10 ranking, Kyrgios admitted to feeling fatigued and uncharacteristically quiet during the match, attributing this to exhaustion from travel and poor sleep. He also mentioned the taxing commute to Qi Zhong Stadium, located an hour from Shanghai. Kyrgios had previously criticized the Shanghai Masters, calling it a "circus" last year, for which he was fined $1,500.

The passage discusses the potential expansion of the HPV vaccination program in Wales to include boys, as advocated by scientists and charities. Currently, only girls aged 12 and 13 receive the vaccine to protect against cervical cancer. The human papilloma virus (HPV) is linked to increasing cases of head and neck cancers, affecting younger demographics, including men, with an average age of 55, most of whom are non-smokers. Charities like Tenovus Cancer Care, along with organizations such as BMA Cymru and Cardiff University's HPV research team, are urging the Welsh government to extend vaccinations to boys to curb these cancer rates. They argue that HPV causes 5% of global cancer cases and that Wales could lead in public health by acting now. The Welsh government states it is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision. Since 2008, 85% of girls in Wales have been vaccinated.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy from West Lothian, passed away after battling a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Diagnosed in August, Jak had been documenting his journey on social media through the page "Jak's Journey," gaining over 28,000 followers. Known for his positive attitude, Jak touched many lives, meeting football stars and receiving honors like the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award. Despite his declining health, he briefly attended his school prom, organized in his honor, and was visited by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. After doctors revealed in January that his cancer had spread and treatment would stop, Jak expressed gratitude to his supporters and asked for donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. In his final days, he enjoyed meaningful experiences like visiting the Kelpies, sharing a meal with his girlfriend, and attending a party in his honor. A charity football match is planned to continue raising funds in his memory.

In a tightly contested match, Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda thanks to a late goal by Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside earlier in the second half. Egypt, seven-time champions, struggled to break down Uganda's resolute defense for much of the game, with few clear chances created by either side. The win keeps Egypt in contention for the top spot in Group D as they prepare to face Ghana, while Uganda, eliminated from their first tournament since 1978, will play Mali in their final group match. Ghana earlier secured their quarter-final spot with a 1-0 win over Mali. The match ended with Egypt 1, Uganda 0.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus as potential sites for a new railway station in Skelmersdale. Both sites are currently unused, with Glenburn Sports College closing in August and the Westbank campus owned by Newcastle College. This decision follows a comparative study by Network Rail, which also considered a site near the Concourse shopping centre. Under plans developed with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, Skelmersdale could receive two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. Councillor John Fillis described the choice as an "exciting step forward," citing the site's potential for future expansion, good highway access, and connectivity. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in northwest England without a railway station, with its original station closing in 1956.
Police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was found seriously injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, also of Kurdish origin, turned himself in to authorities. The motive for the attack remains unclear. Police have secured the scene and are seeking witnesses.

The research conducted by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin challenges the "reticent female" theory, finding that women are as likely as men to request a pay rise but are 25% less likely to receive one when compared to their male counterparts. Analyzing data from 4,600 workers in the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, the study eliminated the impact of part-time versus full-time work by comparing workers in similar employment categories. Factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications were considered. The findings indicate no evidence that women avoid asking for raises due to fear of upsetting their boss or conforming to stereotypes. Professor Andrew Oswald noted the possibility of discrimination against women in pay negotiations and suggested that Australia, while unique in recording pay rise requests, is likely representative of broader industrial economies. The study also revealed that younger women, under 40, negotiate pay rises at the same rate as men, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behavior that may continue as they advance in their careers.

Oxford City Council has been struggling to find a suitable new burial site despite using funds for ground investigations. The two remaining cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council continues to explore options, but challenges such as unsuitable land size, poor ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants have hindered progress. Once the existing cemeteries are full, only limited options like reopening family plots, using reserved plots, or interring ashes will be available. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, will feature an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online content like videos and band interviews via signs and posters. Taking place from 19 to 22 July, the festival includes acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Skerryvore. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlighted the app as an enhancement for attendees and a way for global audiences to engage with the festival, access information, purchase tickets, and experience its unique atmosphere remotely. Content will be updated leading up to and during the event.

The passage details the tragic death of Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, who collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed the cause of death as a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," despite the horse having no significant underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, such as overheating and wobbling, but no such symptoms were observed before his death. The horse was celebrated for his past victories, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood hailed him as the "horse of a lifetime." The BHA emphasized the rarity of such incidents and committed to further research to understand and prevent them. Though Many Clouds had been monitored for previous health concerns, the report concludes the haemorrhage was an uncommon occurrence unrelated to prior conditions.

In 2004, a 15-year-old girl was raped by David Ayrton, now 34 and identifying as Davina, in a Portsmouth garage. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, denied the charge but was remanded into custody by Judge Ian Pearson, likely to be held at a male prison in Winchester. The judge cited risks of self-harm and non-attendance if Ayrton were released on bail. During the trial at Portsmouth Crown Court, Ayrton discussed her sexuality and revealed she had not made physical changes or taken medication; she changed her name in 2012. The court heard that the victim, who had consumed minimal alcohol, clearly remembered the attack and had tried to stop Ayrton, but her friends asleep nearby did not wake up. In 2014, Ayrton disclosed the attack to a care home worker. Protocols were established for her detention, and sentencing is scheduled for 4 March. The judge described the case as unusual and challenging.

The passage highlights a tennis match where Serbian players lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilian duo Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This followed Novak Djokovic's singles elimination by Juan Martin del Potro. Earlier in July, Djokovic, the world number one, experienced an unexpected third-round loss at Wimbledon to Sam Querrey. However, he rebounded by securing his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The passage describes an upcoming chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, featuring over 20 participants from various countries, including Scotland, Europe, Canada, and the US. Competitors are restricted to using only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will compete again to defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a Welsh rugby player, is recovering from a serious foot injury sustained in September and is nearing a return to play. He is currently in a pre-season training phase and aims to be fit before the Six Nations in February. Although a return at the start of February was initially discussed, he hopes to return earlier. Webb, who has earned 16 caps for Wales, recently renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region where he debuted in 2007. He expressed his commitment to playing for Wales and his satisfaction with the new contract. Wales' Six Nations campaign begins on February 7 against Ireland in Dublin.

On Tuesday morning, U.S. border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near the border east of Sumas, Washington. The agents interrupted an attempt to smuggle 58 pounds of MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. One man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested immediately, while the other, Canadian citizen Nathan Hall, fled after firing a weapon but was arrested early Wednesday. Inside the backpacks were drugs and a California driver’s license with Hall’s picture but another name. Two others, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were later arrested for allegedly planning to transport the drugs; Lambert claimed he was to be paid $11,000. Henifin admitted to monitoring police communications. The wooded smuggling route is known for drug and firearm trafficking. The defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant rise in children seeking help for online abuse, with over 4,500 cases in the past year compared to 2,400 in 2011-12. Many victims are as young as seven, describing experiences of torment and fear. Online trolls have caused widespread misery, according to the charity. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasized that cyber-bullying follows children beyond school, making it inescapable. She urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene, warning that bullying worsens if ignored. Schools are encouraged to take the issue seriously, and children are advised to seek help. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which collaborates with parents, schools, and organizations. One child recounted online harassment, highlighting the emotional toll and the need for understanding from parents. Advice from young people on handling bullying is also shared.

The passage discusses the political tension between Israel and the US following a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlement expansion in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The US abstained from vetoing the resolution, which infuriated Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the White House of aiding in drafting the resolution—a claim the US denied. The resolution declared Israeli settlements illegal under international law and an obstacle to a two-state solution. Israel responded by recalling ambassadors, cutting aid to Senegal, and postponing a vote on new settlement homes ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry, who is expected to address the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and counter Israeli critiques of the Obama administration. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution, viewing it as a step toward resolving the conflict at an upcoming peace conference in France.

The passage discusses the events and sentiments surrounding Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday celebrations. Prince William, in a BBC interview, praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch, highlighting her duty, service, and commitment. He addressed criticisms of being "work-shy," asserting that he takes his responsibilities seriously but is finding his own path to royal duty, supported by both the Queen and Prince Charles. A new set of stamps featuring four generations of the Royal Family was released to mark the occasion, and the Queen, accompanied by Prince Philip, participated in events including visiting Windsor's Royal Mail office and unveiling a plaque for The Queen's Walkway. Celebrations also included beacon lightings, a walk around Windsor, and a visit from US President Barack Obama. The Queen's milestone was met with widespread acknowledgment, though some, like the republican group Republic, criticized the extensive media coverage as excessive. The Queen celebrates two birthdays annually, her actual birthday on April 21 and an official one in June.

West Ham United secured a 2-0 victory over Cheltenham Town in an EFL Cup match, with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew before halftime. Sakho scored his first goal since November, assisted by Sam Byram, followed by Ayew's strike moments later. Despite Cheltenham's efforts, including a notable chance from Harry Pell and a sliding attempt by Dan Holman, they were unable to test West Ham goalkeeper Adrian sufficiently. West Ham, who made seven changes to their lineup following recent Premier League losses, had additional opportunities to extend their lead but were thwarted by Cheltenham's defense, including a crucial clearance by Kyle Storer and a save by goalkeeper Jonathan Flatt. Cheltenham, unchanged from their prior league defeat, exited the competition, ending League Two's representation before the third-round draw. The match concluded with West Ham comfortably in control, despite some missed chances and late substitutions from both sides.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, turned his VW Transporter without seeing McNicholl, resulting in the fatal crash. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and was fined £1,000, receiving a two-year UK driving ban. The victim's family, who saw no benefit in jailing Werner, acknowledged it as a momentary lapse. Werner, described as remorseful, could not explain the crash, according to his defense.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, is considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from Syria. He left the UK in January of the previous year, joining the conflict under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani and becoming a prominent online figure, although always masked. Khawaja was part of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, known for its sophisticated propaganda targeting young British Muslims. He participated in appeals for donations and video diaries, contributing to the group's portrayal of jihad as glamorous and noble, despite the reality of gruesome violence. Khawaja's activities included a shocking image of him holding a bag containing a severed head. After faking his death online, he attempted to return to the UK but was arrested upon arrival at Dover. He faces life imprisonment for his involvement in terrorist activities, while his cousin Tahir Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting him. Khawaja’s intentions for returning remain unclear, but his actions, including concealing his re-entry, have marked him as a significant threat.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old footballer, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham, who finished eighth in the table. He has now become Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley. Barnsley's caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson for his speed and ability to challenge defenders, stating he will suit the team's style of play. Jackson rejected a contract offer from Wrexham for next season. For more football transfer updates, readers are directed to a dedicated page.

A surge of detergent bottles began arriving at Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves in Cornwall, believed to be from a container lost overboard from a ship during stormy weather near Land's End in May. The National Trust and volunteers have been clearing the bottles, as they pose a risk to wildlife, with concerns about detergent leakage harming sensitive marine life. While it is confirmed that the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of 'Vanish' detergent, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency states there is no definitive evidence linking the washed-up bottles to this incident. Cornwall Council and partners are monitoring the situation, advising the public to avoid handling the bottles and to keep children and pets at a safe distance. The company Vanish has not yet commented.

A traffic incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at approximately 14:00, resulting in minor injuries to several people. The road was closed, with diversions routed via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland are continuing their investigation into the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, played a key role in helping Bolton Wanderers secure promotion to the Championship by finishing second in League One last season. Having joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014, Dervite has made 83 total appearances. After limited playing time earlier in the season, he made significant contributions towards the end of the campaign, earning praise from manager Phil Parkinson. Dervite is one of several players, including David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, to sign new contracts following the team's promotion.

The passage highlights a disagreement between the Liberal Democrats and Labour over their strategies concerning Brexit amendments. Lord Oates of the Lib Dems accused Labour of conceding too much, while Labour's Baroness Smith claimed the Lib Dems were offering "false hope." Despite previous cooperation that led to government defeats on issues like EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal approvals, their alliance faltered when MPs rejected these amendments. Labour deferred to the Commons, whereas the Lib Dems pushed on. A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems for "grandstanding" for campaign purposes, while Baroness Ludford of the Lib Dems accused Labour of aligning with the Conservatives on a "hard Brexit." Although the two parties have a history of collaboration on various issues, tensions persist, with Labour predicting residual friction and skepticism about future cooperation. Nonetheless, the Lib Dems expressed optimism about working with others on shared goals.

In this election, defence is a low priority for most political parties, ranking behind issues like the economy, NHS, and immigration. Despite a growing sense of global instability and threats, UK defence spending has decreased, with the size of the military and its capabilities significantly reduced. Defence spending has fallen to 1.7% of GDP, and the UK is now the sixth-largest global spender, behind the US, China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, and France. While the commitment to spend 2% of GDP on defence is waning, only smaller parties like UKIP and the DUP pledge to maintain it. The UK’s armed forces face capability gaps, with reductions in warships, aircraft squadrons, and personnel, while key decisions loom on replacing Trident and funding new aircraft carriers. Political parties are divided on nuclear deterrence, and further defence cuts seem likely, jeopardizing the UK’s global military standing and its credibility with allies like the US. Despite promises to renew military equipment, financial constraints may force difficult choices in the next parliament.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar in a transfer that ultimately cost the club £106.8m when including fees, wages, and taxes. The Spanish champions faced accusations of financial mismanagement, leading to the resignation of president Sandro Rosell, who denies wrongdoing. A judge ruled there was enough evidence to investigate the transfer, with allegations suggesting the actual cost of Neymar was higher than initially stated. To address potential discrepancies and protect their reputation, Barcelona made an additional tax payment of €13.5m, though they maintain their original tax obligations were fulfilled. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season. It remains unclear if the case will be dropped following the payment.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father from Nottingham, tragically died as a passenger in a van hit by a wrong-way driver, Albert Kenneth Newman, who also perished. Luciw's family, describing him as generous and kind-hearted, emphasized the need for regular driving tests for older drivers, arguing that age-related slowed reactions can pose risks. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must self-assess every three years to renew their licenses without mandatory medical or driving tests. Luciw’s colleague, Andy Harrington, the van driver, sustained serious injuries and supports medical examinations for retired drivers. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) states there is no evidence that older drivers cause more accidents and prioritizes supporting their independence. Age UK highlights the importance of enabling older people to drive safely for as long as possible.

Many women have raised concerns about the safety of transvaginal mesh implants, used to treat incontinence, due to debilitating side effects. An independent review faced controversy when two patient representatives, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, quit, claiming the final report was watered down. Alison Britton, a professor of healthcare and medical law, has been appointed to examine the review process and identify lessons for the future. The report advised against routine use of the procedure for pelvic organ prolapse, recommending instead that patients be given a range of treatment options and informed choices. It also called for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the government stated it lacks the authority to ban the procedures, as this power lies with the UK’s Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. Tracey Gillies, the review’s chairwoman, apologized for failing to unite panel members and acknowledged the challenges of the task. The controversy followed resignations of other experts and highlighted the experiences of over 20,000 women in Scotland who received the implants, some of whom suffered complications and are now pursuing legal action.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5,000m record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, achieving a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan expressed excitement about her record being broken but initially questioned whether Muir's race—a mixed 3K/5K event where she was the only 5K runner—met UK Athletics' criteria for record ratification, such as being a "genuine race" and undergoing drug testing. British Athletics confirmed the time would likely be ratified, as doping control is not mandatory if not conducted during the event. McColgan praised Muir's potential, stating she could achieve a time closer to 14:30, compete with the world's best, and win world medals with improved race tactics. McColgan noted similarities between Muir's race and her own record-breaking run 25 years ago, including lapping competitors. She also highlighted Muir's achievements, such as breaking her own British 1,500m record and reaching the Rio 2016 Olympic final, while celebrating Muir as a fellow Scot and world-class athlete.

Jung won aboard Sam, a late replacement after Fischertakinou's infection. France's Astier Nicolas claimed silver, and American Phillip Dutton took bronze, while GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th despite a strong show-jumping phase. Fox-Pitt, recovering from a coma after a fall 10 months prior, had his medal chances hindered by a poor cross-country performance. Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth. The passage also mentions opportunities to engage with equestrian sports through Team GB fan parks and a guide to getting involved.

In a tense match, British tennis player Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes at the Championships. Despite Fognini's five set points to force a fifth set, Murray rallied to win five consecutive games, securing his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. He is set to play Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Murray described the match as "up and down" and acknowledged challenges like fading light and his own movement issues. Meanwhile, fellow Briton Johanna Konta reached the second week for the first time. Murray expressed relief at avoiding a fifth set and is focusing on improving for his next match.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014 for a sudden death, with police discovering alcohol being served as late as 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered closed for three months by the judge. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside permitted hours. A defense solicitor admitted the bar was improperly run, with licensing laws not strictly followed. The judge criticized O'Neill’s "appalling record," noting the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence, and fined her £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP), launched the party's manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership,' with a focus on partnership over domination in governance. He framed the election as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, criticizing "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption." Nesbitt faced scrutiny over his remarks suggesting post-election cooperation with the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin, which prompted senior colleague Danny Kennedy to publicly distance himself. Nesbitt defended his comments, asserting they were consistent with his vision for post-election collaboration and denying any regrets. The manifesto highlights policies such as tackling healthcare waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing infrastructure projects, supporting the LGBT community, and protecting groups affected by Brexit. It also calls for reforms to improve transparency and accountability at Stormont. Despite controversy over his remarks, Nesbitt expressed confidence in his strategy and reported strong support in unionist areas.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed that a motion will be presented to the Northern Ireland Assembly to approve pardons for men convicted of abolished sexual offenses, aligning with measures recently announced in England and Wales under 'Turing's Law.' This law, named after WWII code-breaker Alan Turing, grants posthumous pardons to deceased individuals and allows living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons. The motion seeks to provide equal treatment for men in Northern Ireland, ensuring pardons for both past and living convicts. Sugden emphasized the need for swift action to address past injustices and achieve parity with England and Wales. The motion is now set for assembly consideration.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish 1500m record with a time of 4:19.12, placing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This time surpasses Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and positions Muir second on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who finished fifth in the previous World Championships, expressed pride in achieving the Scottish record and is excited about her performance, especially as this was her first race of the season over this distance. She also holds the Scottish mile record. Muir aims to secure an Olympics spot for Great Britain at the upcoming British trials. Balancing her veterinary studies, she recently completed her fourth year of vet school and has started her season with an 800m victory in France, with her next race scheduled in Stockholm. Training has been going well, contributing to her strong performance. Yvonne Murray, whose record was broken, congratulated Muir via her husband's Facebook post.
The passage mentions that there are 26 beaches in Scotland ranked as having "most excellent" water quality, and it invites viewers to see pictures of these beaches.

The passage discusses the case of Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian agent who was poisoned with polonium-210 in London in 2006, leading to his death. Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi likely had no personal motive to kill Litvinenko, but suggested the Russian state was probably involved, given "reasons aplenty" for wanting him dead. Litvinenko, who defected to the UK and accused the FSB of corruption and murder, had also made personal attacks on Vladimir Putin. While the involvement of the Russian state is strongly implied, Horwell clarified there is no evidence directly linking Putin to the murder. Litvinenko was poisoned twice, and the suspects left a "trail of polonium," with no credible defense against the scientific evidence. Though extradition attempts have failed and a trial for murder is unlikely, the long-term public health risks from the polonium exposure remain unknown. The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the ongoing captain of Australia's one-day and Twenty20 teams, replacing the injured Aaron Finch, with David Warner, 28, as his vice-captain. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and leadership qualities, expressing confidence in his ability to succeed despite the retirement of former captain Michael Clarke, 34, following Australia's Ashes defeat. Smith previously led the team in three Tests against India and has an impressive record in Test cricket. Warner, despite past disciplinary issues, is deemed mature enough for the vice-captain role. Both will lead in upcoming limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test.

The passage discusses a political figure's stance on LGBT+ rights and his past voting record. Despite refusing to directly answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, the individual asserts his strong commitment to LGBT+ rights and equal marriage, which he claims will be a top priority in his leadership. He also advocates for extending marital rights to transgender people, criticizing the spousal veto that requires consent from a spouse for a marriage to continue after one partner transitions. Although he voted against the 2007 Equality Bill, he justifies this by citing concerns over "protection of individual liberties" and maintains his support for equal legal access for all, regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Now, Accord Healthcare plans to use the facility for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi employees. Accord’s investment is expected to positively impact the local economy. Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes praised the move, highlighting its significance for the region’s science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical company, produces over 130 products for about 60 countries.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving the local council, with Ellis departing at the end of his contract and Monaghan and Sutherland exiting via voluntary redundancy and early retirement. Ellis served as interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, while Monaghan led the chief executive's office and Sutherland headed human resources and customer services. Opposition SNP group leader Stephen Flynn criticized the council for its inability to retain senior staff, predicting more departures. Council chief executive Angela Scott praised the three for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, Martin, experienced a challenging year with mechanical issues affecting his Fireblade bike and a crash at the TT. Initially announcing his retirement from road racing, he later clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up racing entirely but has no plans to race Hondas this year. Martin skipped the North West 200 after his teammate's crash and will not participate in the Ulster Grand Prix, as the bike was deemed uncompetitive. He expressed dissatisfaction with the TT, feeling more like a test rider, and mentioned his interest in racing classics and other unique events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) achieved a significant victory in Nigeria's gubernatorial elections, securing 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking the largest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential election last month, saw its influence diminish particularly in northern states, including Katsina and Kaduna, and in Adamawa, a region affected by Boko Haram. However, the PDP retained control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, posing challenges for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari regarding oil revenue and militant groups. Elections were marred by violence in some areas, particularly in Rivers and other southern states, though overall, they were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP, having been in power for 16 years, faces a period of introspection and rebuilding after allegations of corruption and failure to adequately address the insurgency in the north-east contributed to its decline. The APC's control of Lagos, the commercial capital, is a first since 1999, and underscores the party's growing national influence.

The passage discusses allegations made by Mighty, a US-based environmental group, against Olam, an agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Singapore's state-owned investment company Temasek. Mighty accuses Olam of indirectly supporting unsustainable palm oil practices contributing to haze in Southeast Asia, primarily caused by slash-and-burn agriculture in Indonesia. Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, denies the claims, asserting a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy. Despite this, Mighty's report suggests Olam's sourcing may encourage rogue palm oil traders, a claim Olam refutes, stating its suppliers meet sustainable requirements, though verification is ongoing. Temasek also rejects allegations linking it to haze issues through its investment in Olam, emphasizing its support for no-burn policies. The palm oil industry faces criticism globally for environmental destruction, labor issues, and deforestation, with tensions between NGOs and industry executives over regulation and compliance. Additionally, Mighty accuses Olam of unsustainable practices in Gabon, where Olam defends its operations as responsible and transparent, aligning with Gabon's agricultural development plans. Both companies and governments face challenges in balancing economic benefits with environmental protection.

The passage describes a restaurant that started serving puppy platters following a new law that permits dogs to dine at restaurants, provided they are outdoors. The situation is humorously referred to as a "dog's dinner," with an accompanying clip highlighted.

Fernando Forestieri is uncertain for the upcoming game due to a knee injury, having been limited to bench appearances in the last two matches. David Nugent may return for Derby County after missing the previous game with a groin issue. Jacob Butterfield is seeking a starting position following his late equalizing goal as a substitute.

Pakistan lifted its ban on YouTube after the platform launched a Pakistan-specific version. The ban, imposed in 2012 by the Supreme Court, was a response to the controversial film *Innocence of Muslims*, which sparked protests and violence in the Muslim world. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) confirmed that internet service providers were instructed to restore access, with the government stating that Google would enable a process for the PTA to request blocking of specific content deemed offensive. However, YouTube emphasized that removal requests would be reviewed thoroughly and not automatically granted, in line with its community guidelines. Activists have called for transparency regarding the agreement between Google and the government. YouTube's local launches in Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka were also recently announced. Blasphemy remains a serious offense in Pakistan, punishable by law.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces calls to withdraw from overseeing the upcoming FIFA presidential election due to a perceived conflict of interest, as he shares Swiss-Italian nationality with candidate Gianni Infantino. Musa Bility, head of Liberia's FA, threatens legal action via the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down, citing Article 7.4 of FIFA's Electoral Regulations, which bars committee members with conflicts of interest. Scala previously recused himself in 2015 when Swiss candidate Sepp Blatter ran, but his spokesperson argues there is no formal rule requiring recusal based on nationality, and no conflict exists this time with no incumbent president. Bility questions why the same voluntary recusal process hasn't been followed ahead of the February 26 election, emphasizing the need for fairness after FIFA's turbulent period. Bility, disqualified from running in November, has endorsed Prince Ali and urged African nations to support him. The election will see five candidates vying to replace Blatter, with voting conducted by FIFA's 209 members in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a suspected flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, where they were working in a paint-spraying area. The incident occurred shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday, and their bodies were removed the following afternoon. A forensic investigation suggests the explosion was caused by a buildup of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, creating a fireball effect. Significant progress has been made in the investigation, with evidence collection and witness statements underway. The Health and Safety Executive is also gathering evidence, involving inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints made during the 2015 tournament. Morocco, having faced a ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), also qualified for the 2017 qualifiers. Morocco was initially punished for refusing to host the 2015 Cup over Ebola fears, but Cas reduced their fine significantly. Tunisia's dispute with Caf stemmed from a contentious penalty in a 2015 quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea, which they lost 2-1. Tunisia contested the referee's choice and the situation escalated to a threat of expulsion unless they apologized, which they did following a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Both Tunisia and Morocco are now preparing for the qualifiers, with Tunisia aiming for a record thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

In the 95th minute of Chelsea's 3-1 win over Manchester City at Etihad Stadium, a mass confrontation occurred. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action, while City's Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for a violent challenge on David Luiz, marking his second dismissal this season. Fernandinho, involved in a clash with Fabregas during the incident, was handed a three-match suspension. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's role, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Cymru a rhannau o'r DU wynebu cyfraddau uchel o goresgyn canser, gan arwain at gynllun peilot yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd i wella diagnosis canser. Y cynllun yw canolbwyntio ar gleifion heb symptomau gliriach trwy eu cyfeirio o fewn saith diwrnod at ganolfannau ddiagnostig, lle gobeithir y bydd profion yn cael eu cynnig ar yr un diwrnod. Mae disgwyl i chwe chlaf yr wythnos gael eu gweld yn y cynllun. Os yn llwyddiannus, bydd y gwasanaeth yn cael ei gynnig ar draws byrddau iechyd Cymru, gan gynnig gobaith am ddiagnosis cynnar ac effeithlonrwydd uwch i achub bywydau.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with their second-largest win against Pakistan in terms of runs. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, with Joe Root named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, alongside contributing with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root’s performance, calling it one of the best innings he’s seen. Root, who had struggled in the first Test, attributed his success to improved focus and discipline. Coach Trevor Bayliss noted Root’s dedication to self-improvement. Pakistan’s batting faltered, with their spirit described as "broken" by Geoffrey Boycott, as they managed only 198 and 234. Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment, citing poor shot selection and low confidence as key issues. Despite the loss, Misbah remains hopeful his team will recover. The third Test is set for Edgbaston on 3 August, with both teams anticipating a tightly contested series.

Warren Gatland, leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, has included Rob Howley in his backroom team. Forwards coach Robin McBryde will take on head coach responsibilities for Wales during the summer tour, marking his third time in the role after tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed pride in representing his country overseas and looks forward to the opportunity. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) plans to appoint assistant coaches and finalize the management team soon. WRU chairman Gareth Davies highlights the benefits of Welsh coaches gaining experience in different environments, particularly through involvement with the Lions, which he believes will invigorate Welsh rugby. He emphasized the mental stimulation and inspiration gained from the challenge of touring New Zealand.

In a dramatic match, Hull City ended a six-game losing streak with a 2-1 victory over Southampton, despite early setbacks. Charlie Austin's early penalty put Southampton in control, but Hull fought back after losing their starting strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, to first-half injuries. Robert Snodgrass, returning from injury, transformed the game by scoring in the 61st minute and providing an assist for Michael Dawson's header two minutes later. Hull's goalkeeper, David Marshall, made crucial saves to deny Southampton an equalizer, and Sam Clucas executed a vital goalline clearance in added time. The win marked Hull's first league victory since August and lifted spirits, though they remain in the relegation zone. Southampton, who had previously celebrated a notable Europa League win, were left to rue their lack of urgency. Both managers acknowledged the challenges faced, with Hull's Mike Phelan praising his team's resilience and Southampton's Claude Puel emphasizing the need for improved concentration. Following the international break, Hull will face Sunderland, while Southampton will host Liverpool.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist was a local resident, and the tractor driver involved was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police have requested witnesses to come forward. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov of Macedonia canceled an investigation into alleged abuse of power revealed by covert recordings to ease tensions before June elections, stating he aimed to "defend national interests." The decision drew criticism from both the opposition and EU officials, with EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn warning it jeopardized Macedonia's EU membership aspirations. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev labeled the move illegal and called for protests in Skopje, drawing hundreds. The political crisis began in 2015 when recordings suggested government corruption, including vote-rigging and a cover-up of a murder. Zaev has released numerous recordings since, accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 individuals and engaging in high-level corruption, allegations the government denies, accusing Zaev of attempting to destabilize the country instead.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as the preferred candidate, to avoid relegation. Curtis, a former player who witnessed the club's rise from near-bankruptcy to the Premier League, believes the team has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, citing frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements. Despite challenges, Curtis is confident in the current squad's ability to avoid relegation. He emphasizes the club's remarkable history to new players, highlighting the importance of staying in the Premier League for the club and the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after losing 3-2 to Leyton Orient, despite a brief comeback attempt with goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona following Orient's 2-0 lead. Armand Gnanduillet's winning goal ended Dagenham's survival hopes in League Two, as they now face the drop under manager John Still, who previously led them from the Conference to League One. Dagenham struggled both defensively and offensively this season, with Cureton scoring just nine goals and the team conceding significantly more goals than last season. Still remains committed to securing promotion next season. Meanwhile, Leyton Orient's victory kept their play-off hopes alive, despite managerial instability after Kevin Nolan's removal. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized professionalism and the importance of winning games to make the play-offs. Still acknowledged Dagenham's organizational and disciplinary shortcomings this season.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain, is set to return to the club as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player in November. The 36-year-old, who had a successful 19-year career including winning the Champions League and other major trophies, expressed his ambition to become a manager in the future. Liverpool's manager, Jürgen Klopp, supported Gerrard's decision, noting his readiness to learn and bright future in management. Gerrard is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, a necessary step for managing in the Premier League. Previously, Gerrard turned down the managerial position at MK Dons, deeming it too soon in his career post-retirement.

McManus scored early from close range, followed by a deflected strike from Ross Forbes, giving Morton a strong lead. Kyle McAusland's goal brought Alloa back into the game before halftime. However, additional goals by McManus and Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable victory for Morton.

Ofsted has discovered children being taught in squalid, unregulated conditions in three Birmingham locations, all now closed, with owners facing investigation for running illegal schools. Illegal school operators could face jail terms of up to 51 weeks. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, warned these cases are likely the "tip of the iceberg," with concerns about child abuse and radicalisation. A total of 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been investigated, and ministers are consulting on stricter regulations for places teaching over 6-8 hours weekly. Schools teaching over 20 hours a week must register, but some exploit home-education laws to operate illegally. Ofsted criticises officials for slow action and confusing advice to proprietors. A team of six inspectors, funded by the government, will investigate illegal schools, targeting unsafe and unhygienic conditions across all religious groups. The Education Secretary plans prosecutions, requiring her consent, and has called for stricter enforcement. The consultation on further regulation concludes in mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, represents a small-scale yet ambitious gin production operation located in a cowshed, utilizing one of the UK's smallest production stills. It highlights the Scottish Borders' local botanicals and "terroir," aiming to capture the region's unique flavors. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes emphasizes the potential to establish the area as a "region of distilling excellence." The gin's name honors Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure associated with the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor. The distillery aligns with the site's Scottish Borders Brewery, sharing an ethos of local sourcing. John Henderson of Born in the Borders praises the venture as a significant step in hosting the region's first distillery in nearly 200 years.

Harry Whitlam was tragically killed in August 2013 when Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal alcohol limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm near Leeds. Green, who had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before sleeping and later admitted failing to ensure the safety of others, was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail. The incident occurred on private land, leading to Green's prosecution under health and safety laws rather than road traffic laws. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, described the profound impact of the loss on her family, emphasizing the dangers of drunk driving and expressing hope to remember Harry’s life beyond the tragedy. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) labeled the case as "extremely tragic," with an inspector calling Green's actions "reckless."

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan striker who transferred to Barcelona for £75 million, has been allowed to train and participate in friendly matches following a Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) ruling. This decision modifies his original FIFA-imposed four-month ban for biting Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup, allowing him to engage in "football-related activities" but still prohibiting him from playing in competitive matches. Suarez must complete the remaining eight games of his nine-match international ban and is ineligible for Barcelona's competitive games until El Clasico against Real Madrid on 26 October. 

The ruling enables Suarez to participate in Uruguay's upcoming friendly matches and promotional activities. While the Cas upheld FIFA's sanctions, it deemed the initial ban from all football-related activities as "excessive" and disproportionate. Suarez's legal team argued that FIFA misapplied its rules, and his lawyers considered the appeal a success. World players' union Fifpro expressed disappointment, advocating for reduced sanctions tied to mandatory treatment. Suarez’s history of misconduct, including prior biting incidents and a racial abuse suspension, was noted, with legal experts emphasizing proportionality in sanctions for repeat offenders. Suarez publicly apologized for the biting incident nearly a week later.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race on 18 March 2014, beating Lithuanian competitors Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race involved a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols, and participants included various combinations of men and women carrying each other. Richard credited their victory to a week of training on an athletics track and acknowledged the challenge posed by their competitors. They plan to compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the transition from paper car tax discs to an electronic system in October 2014, announced by Chancellor George Osborne. This change raised concerns about potential job losses among the 5,000 employees at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) in Swansea. In response, Stephen Hammond, a minister, assured Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that while job roles may change and require new training, there would be no redundancies. Instead, employees would be redeployed to other growing areas within the DVLA. Hedges welcomed the clarification, noting that although job opportunities may decrease, the new system offers benefits like monthly direct debit payments and the elimination of physical tax discs. He expressed relief that the minister prioritized redeployment over job cuts, providing reassurance to employees.

The passage discusses Hungary's resistance to EU interference in its domestic policies, specifically concerning asylum seeker controls, NGO regulations, and a higher education law. Hungarian Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó stated that Hungary would not backtrack on these laws, asserting they fall under national jurisdiction. He also claimed Poland's support in vetoing any EU sanctions against Hungary, which would require unanimous approval. The EU opposes these laws, particularly the education law that may lead to the closure of the Central European University, founded by George Soros. Additionally, Hungary's detention of asylum seekers in shipping containers and upcoming legislation labeling NGOs as "foreign-backed" have raised concerns about compliance with EU law and human rights. Despite pressure from EU officials like Frans Timmermans, Hungary’s government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, remains defiant. Protests have occurred in Hungary against these measures.

The passage discusses the casting and release details for the live-action adaptation of Disney's "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson will play Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast and Luke Evans as Gaston. Josh Gad will portray LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. Kevin Kline is cast as Maurice, Belle's father, and a star will play Mrs. Potts, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is set for US release on 17 March 2017 and begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a celebrated journalist and writer for the Sunday Times, passed away after being diagnosed with a severe form of cancer, which he described as the "full English." Despite his illness, Gill remained stoical and expressed gratitude for his life. Known for his fearless, witty, and compassionate writing, he was regarded as a giant among journalists and the "heart and soul" of the Sunday Times, where he worked since 1993. His final column, addressing his cancer diagnosis, was set to be published posthumously. Tributes poured in from colleagues and public figures, praising his unique style, brilliance, and kindness, despite his often controversial and provocative articles. Overcoming dyslexia, Gill built a distinguished career, writing art reviews before joining the Sunday Times. He leaves behind his partner Nicola Formby, with whom he had two children, and two children from his previous marriage to Amber Rudd. Gill's death has left a profound impact on his colleagues and the journalism community.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator, Mongolia's capital, by a Russian diplomatic officer. Reports claim he was struck with a bottle and kicked repeatedly in the face, leaving him in a coma for about 10 days with serious injuries, including brain damage. Sukhbaatar had performed wearing a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, a symbol tied to Mongolian culture and history, though controversial due to its Nazi associations. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, calling local reports "distorted." Sukhbaatar's lawyer emphasized the need for investigation under Mongolian law, noting the suspect wasn't detained due to the injury's perceived severity, not diplomatic immunity. The case remains under investigation, with no arrest made. The rapper's family and lawyer denied claims he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the performance, and Sukhbaatar frequently uses traditional symbols and themes in his music.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against airport expansion plans by staging a demonstration on Monday at 03:30 BST on the northern runway. Participants were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted aerodrome area and are set to appear in court on 19 August. Following the protest, the Metropolitan Police announced a review of airport security.

Nick Selman scored a crucial 101 off 144 balls, marking his second first-class century, which helped Glamorgan recover from a series of low scores this season. Despite his efforts, consistent wicket-taking by Gloucestershire's seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles kept the opposition in check amid challenging batting conditions. Aneurin Donald contributed a rapid 36, but Glamorgan struggled to build substantial partnerships, ending the day with a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire’s innings faced difficulties in the evening, leaving the match evenly poised. Selman expressed satisfaction with his form resurgence despite his dismissal soon after reaching a century, acknowledging the challenges of opening in county cricket. Matt Taylor highlighted the bowlers' advantage on the pitch and emphasized the need for resilience from Gloucestershire's batsmen moving forward. Glamorgan is led by Michael Hogan due to Jacques Rudolph's injury.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested in August after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre, raising fears of a planned attack on police. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court, including making a false report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary, where he planned to shoot them. The threats were made late at night while Hughes was intoxicated. He has a prior conviction for firearm possession in 2009 and was on bail for other firearms offences at the time, though he was later cleared of those. Hughes's legal team claimed he had no intention of harming himself or executing the threats. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody, with sentencing scheduled for the following week. The Hope Line Centre provides confidential support to individuals in crisis.

Surrey posted a score of 255-7 against Yorkshire, with a significant 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes, who scored 90. Yorkshire's chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, which included key players Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan’s 68, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Yorkshire had hoped to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002, but their efforts were undermined by missed opportunities, including a dropped catch of Davies. Meaker's pivotal bowling and Surrey's crucial wickets ensured Yorkshire’s defeat. Surrey's captain praised his team's unity and the impactful partnership, while Yorkshire's captain expressed disappointment over their performance when it mattered most.

A 56ft converted trawler located 6 miles west of South Stack encountered trouble when its onboard pump failed to handle incoming water. The crew contacted Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST. The RNLI lifeboat crew intervened, providing an additional pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

The passage discusses Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir's decision to prioritize her veterinary medicine studies over competing in the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast. Muir, who recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, explained that her exams in May conflict with the April event. Despite her disappointment, she emphasized the importance of completing her degree. Muir expressed optimism about future competitions, including potentially targeting the World Indoor Championships in March and aiming for success in upcoming Olympics. She also reflected on her personal best performance in the 5,000m at the World Championships, highlighting her satisfaction with her progress and future potential.

The passage discusses Liverpool's struggles to replicate last season's title challenge, focusing on managerial and player-related issues. Liverpool's overachievement last season raised unrealistic expectations, and manager Brendan Rodgers faces criticism, particularly regarding his transfer decisions. The loss of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge have significantly impacted the team's offensive capabilities, with current forwards Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini deemed inadequate. The team lacks intensity and effective pressing, crucial to their previous success, and set-piece goals have drastically reduced. Defensively, Liverpool still struggle despite significant investment, lacking leadership and consistency. The upcoming match against Chelsea highlights these deficiencies, with Chelsea perceived as stronger. Steven Gerrard remains pivotal for Liverpool despite his age and recent errors, facing both physical and mental challenges to extend his career. Gerrard, along with Raheem Sterling and Sturridge, is considered crucial for Liverpool's future, with Rodgers needing to address current shortcomings to secure a top-four finish.

The passage describes plans for a £45m educational facility in Kilmarnock, which will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council intends to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a celebrated writer born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," was passionate about education and began his career as an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975. He gained acclaim for his novels, including the Laidlaw trilogy, and was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributor to Scottish political and sporting life. He passed away in December. Council leader Douglas Reid expressed pride in honoring McIlvanney's legacy.

An area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon due to the discovery of a British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s. Residents within 500 meters were advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside, while an exclusion zone was enforced on the river and at sea. The mine, which could not be safely assessed due to its deterioration, was to be moved to a safer location before being neutralized. The evacuation affected three streets, disrupted local ferry services, and impacted small boat owners. Authorities, including Ch Insp Elliot Brown and Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis, emphasized that the measures were precautionary with no immediate danger to the community. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their cooperation during the operation.

UK Sport has allocated £345m to fund 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, which is £2m less than the funding for Rio 2016. The investment aims for Team GB to win 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Several sports, including badminton, archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, have lost funding, with badminton's removal being particularly controversial due to its Rio bronze medal win. Cycling's funding was also reduced by over £4m despite its previous success. UK Sport prioritizes funding based on medal potential, acknowledging the necessity of tough decisions to maintain Britain's success. Some sports, like judo, saw slight funding increases. Basketball, handball, and volleyball criticize UK Sport for neglecting team sports despite earlier commitments to support their development. New sports added for Tokyo 2020, such as baseball/softball, karate, and skateboarding, await funding confirmation as UK Sport assesses their medal potential.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel with 90 rooms and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine and seven storeys) comprising 122 apartments. English Heritage and 49 residents objected, citing harm to the area's historic character, while 246 letters supported the plans. Councillors approved the project, with a 7-3 vote, arguing it would boost tourism and improve housing for older residents. Councillor David Kelsey acknowledged the loss of buildings but emphasized the need for progress. The Ancient Monuments Society also opposed the plan, highlighting the area's historic value.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely in Brecon while off-duty during a night out. Vallely, who had been on a drinking binge, punched and beat Pte Boyd outside a bar called The Cellar before dragging his body away. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. His friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. CCTV footage showed the assault, and Vallely boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the incident. Pte Boyd, originally from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was in Brecon for training exercises. The attack, described by police as "a despicable act," shocked the community. Pte Boyd's family remembered him as a loving, loyal, and promising young man whose death has left an irreplaceable void. They expressed gratitude for the community's support, countering Vallely's claim by highlighting the strength of those who showed compassion.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left by "mutual agreement" following an error that saw voters turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on poll lists.
